But as this a≈ø≈øurance is excellent, ≈øo is it hard to come by; Difficilia quae pulchra. 'Tis not to be obtained without a great deal of labour and diligence. 'Tis u≈øually

div.head: OF THE ASSURANCE OF OUR VOCATION, AND ELECTION.
SERMON I.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p:
TO give you an account why I pitch'd upon the≈øe words, it is briefly thus. Having ≈øpent ≈øeventeen Sermons in treating of the Glory of Heaven for the Elect, and of the Torments of Hell for the Reprobate; I deem'd it mo≈øt meet to ≈øhut up tho≈øe two Doctrines in the pro≈øecution of this Subject, of the A≈ø≈øurance of our Election and Vocation, that ≈øo if this Doctrine be well improved, you may have e≈øtabli≈øhment in your own hearts, that you are freed from the
torments of the Damned, and may be confident you ≈øhall be ≈øtated into the Glory of Heaven, which God hath provided for all his Saints. And to the end you might have a≈ø≈øurance, that you ≈øhall be freed from the one, and ≈øhall enjoy the other, you mu≈øt make it your work, according to the words of my Text, to make your Calling and Election ≈øure: Make but that ≈øure, and you are ≈øure of Heaven. This is the rea≈øon why I pitch'd upon this Subject: And it is my care in preaching the Word, not to chu≈øe tho≈øe Texts that are mo≈øt for my ea≈øe in ≈øtudy, but for your profit in hearing; that ≈øo one Subject might back another, and one Subject might ≈øtrengthen another, and being put together, might more ≈øerve for your edification and knowledg.
I ≈øhall not ≈øtand long in Prefacing: All that I have to do in the managing of the≈øe words, are the≈øe three things.
1. To ≈øhew you the ≈øcope, and dependance of the words.
2. The ≈øen≈øe and meaning.
3. To draw out tho≈øe practical Ob≈øervations which naturally flow from them: And then apply the Ob≈øervations deduced.

For the ≈øcope and dependance of the≈øe words: you may di≈øcern it lies thus: Peter, who is called an Apo≈øtle of the Circumci≈øion, that is, an Apo≈øtle who≈øe work and Office it was to preach to the Circumci≈øed Jewes (as it was Paul's Office to preach to the uncircumci≈øed Gentiles), he writ this Epi≈øtle to the di≈øper≈øed Jewes, that were ≈øcattered throughout the world, through Pontus, A≈øia, Cappadocia, Galatia and Bythinia: Whence ob≈øerve, Gods people are a ≈øcattered people. And to them he writes, that though they were per≈øons living in different places, yet they had the ≈øame faith: Simon Peter a ≈øervant and an Apo≈øtle of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, to them that have obtained like precious faith. So that you ≈øee, the Spirit of God, where it works in men, though they live in different places, yet they ≈øhall all believe
the ≈øame Truth, and all receive the ≈øame Faith: Though different in Language, yet but one God, and one Faith. The Spirit of God wrought the ≈øame Faith among tho≈øe ≈øcattered Chri≈øtians. And the Apo≈øtle writing to the≈øe Jewes, he begins his Epi≈øtle, fir≈øt by way of Salutation, ver. 2. Grace and peace be multiplied to you. 2. He writes by way of Con≈øolation, ver. 4. telling them that they are Partakers of the Divine Nature, that they are call'd to Glory, and ≈øhall enjoy all the Promi≈øes of the Go≈øpel: The≈øe are the great props with which he bears up their hearts and comforts them by. Then 3. he proceeds by way of Exhortation, and Direction, ver. 5. and that is, that they ≈øhould give diligence to add grace to grace, that they ≈øhould make it their „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or their main bu≈øine≈øs for which they are ≈øent into the world, not only to get grace, but to thrive in grace; and begins with Faith, becau≈øe this is the foundation or mother grace. And this he pre≈ø≈øeth by a double Argument: Fir≈øt, con≈øidering the benefit ≈øhall redound to them, in ca≈øe they perform this duty to labour to thrive in grace, ver. 8. If the≈øe things be in you and abound, they ≈øhall make you that you ≈øhall neither be barren nor unfruitful in the knowledg of the Lord Je≈øus. If you make it your work to grow in grace, you ≈øhall never be a barren or unfruitful people; but you ≈øhall be growing in grace, and thriving in God ≈øtill. 2. From the inconvenience that would accrue, in ca≈øe they ≈øhould neglect this work, ver. 9. He that lacks the≈øe things, is blind, and cannot ≈øee afar off; that is, he that lacks the≈øe graces: if you do not grow in grace, you will be ≈øo dim ≈øighted, you will ≈øo deaden your comforts, and darken your evidences, that you can have no a≈ø≈øurance you ≈øhall be ≈øaved. And then he comes in with a general Exhortation backing all this, that ≈øeeing there is this good comes by adding grace to grace, and ≈øeeing there wil be this evil if you do it not, he brings all home by a practical inference, in the words of my Text, Wherefore, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

The words are not difficult, though indeed they are mangled by the Papi≈øts, who bring this Text to Martyrdome by their corrupt glo≈ø≈øes. I ≈øhall only give you a brief Paraphra≈øtical Explication, and ≈øo come to the Ob≈øervations.

Wherefore:] That you may ≈øee the force of the connexion, it is as much as if the Apo≈øtle ≈øhould ≈øay thus; Seeing there comes ≈øo great good by growing in grace, and ≈øeeing the neglect of it doth ≈øo much hurt, not only to deaden your hearts, but darken your comforts, that you can have no cleer and comfortable evidence for heaven; Therefore give diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.
Wherefore the rather, brethren:] that is, Brethren, not in the fle≈øh, but in the faith of Chri≈øt, imbracing the ≈øame faith, keeping to the ≈øame head; them the Apo≈øtle calls brethren.

Wherefore the rather, brethren, give diligence:]
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . The word in the Greek is, more emphatical, and ≈øignifies to do a thing enough, not agere, but ≈øat agere, not in an overly and carele≈øs way, but to do a thing with indu≈øtry, vigilancy and unweariedne≈øs of ≈øpirit; it ≈øhould not be matter of con≈øtraint, but free and voluntary; Give diligence. And the diligence you ≈øhould u≈øe is in matters of the ≈øoul. Give diligence: In what? To make your Calling and Election ≈øure. Fir≈øt, I mu≈øt ≈øhew you what is meant by Calling; then by Election; and then ≈øhew you why Calling is ≈øet before Election, when in order of time election is before calling.
1. What is meant by Calling; which, that you may under≈øtand, you mu≈øt know there is a twofold Calling, an external, and an internal Calling.

The External Calling is that general invitation, which by the preaching of the Go≈øpel, is made unto men, to invite them to come in to Je≈øus Chri≈øt: and mo≈øt in the world are called by this call, both good and bad.

2. The Internal Calling, when the Spirit of God accompanies the outward admini≈øtration of the word, to call a man from ignorance to knowledg, and from a ≈øtate of nature
to a ≈øtate of grace; and of this Calling my Text means. Make your Calling ≈øure; that is, you that live under the preaching of the Go≈øpel, be ≈øure you be called thereby.

Your calling and election:] Election is an act of God, whereby from all eternity he doth purpo≈øe within him≈øelf, of his own plea≈øure and will, to bring a certain number of men unto ≈øalvation by Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

But now, how can it be ≈øaid, We mu≈øt make our calling and election ≈øure? Doth not the Foundation of God ≈øtand ≈øure, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith? And are not the gifts and calling of God without repentance? How then mu≈øt we make our Election ≈øure, when all the Decrees of God ≈øtand ≈øure?

An≈øw. Beloved, when it is ≈øaid, you mu≈øt make the≈øe ≈øure, you mu≈øt take it in this ≈øen≈øe; not to make them ≈øure on Gods part; for it cannot be made more ≈øure there then it is already; whom he hath elected, ≈øhall be glorified: But make it ≈øure on your parts; that is, Labour to have a real, bottom'd, and grounded a≈ø≈øurance that you are effectually called, that you are elected by God in his eternal Decree, to obtain life and glorie by Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Divines therefore give this di≈øtinction; Certitudo Objecti, & certitudo Subjecti. That there is an a≈ø≈øurance of the Object, and that is ≈øure enough; for if God hath decreed you to glorie, that will hold ≈øure for ever. But then, there is a certitude of the Subject, an a≈ø≈øurance to the per≈øon that is elected; and that is, when by a reflex act of faith you have a grounded per≈øwa≈øion in your own bre≈øts, that you are effectually called, and eternally elected: An a≈ø≈øurance in your own apprehen≈øion and knowledg.

La≈øtly, Why is Calling here ≈øet before Election, when in order of time Election is before Calling? You are called in time by the preaching of the Go≈øpel, you are elected before all time, before the world: Before the foundation of the world was laid he hath elected us in Chri≈øt, Eph. 1.4. And if ≈øo, What is the rea≈øon that Calling in my Text is put before Election?

An≈øw. To this I an≈øwer, Calling in order of words is placed before Election, not as if it were in time before it; but to ≈øhew, that we can never be ≈øure of our election, till God hath effectually called us by the preaching of the Go≈øpel: and therefore Calling is ≈øet before Election.
Thus I have opened the things mo≈øt material, giving you the ≈øen≈øe of the words.
The whole Ver≈øe is made up of two parts. Fir≈øt, Here is a main duty enjoyned; in the≈øe words, Give diligence to make your calling and election ≈øure.
Secondly, Here is a ≈øtrong inducement to inforce you to this duty; and that in the la≈øt words, If you do the≈øe things, you ≈øhall never fall.
In the Duty injoyned there are ≈øeveral things ob≈øervable:
1. The matter of the duty: To make ≈øure your election and calling.
2. The manner, how you mu≈øt ≈øet about this duty; and that is, with diligence: Give diligence.
3. The motive to draw you to it, in the word Wherefore.
4. Here is the compari≈øon between this duty and all other duties; Wherefore the rather: do this rather then all other things in the world. And

La≈øtly, Here is that loving compellation whereby Peter would gain them to ≈øet upon the ready practice of this dutie, in that word, Brethren; Wherefore Brethren, give diligence to make your calling and election ≈øure.
From the≈øe five Parts there are five Points ob≈øervable.
As 1. From the Matter of the dutie. Make ≈øure your election and vocation. Hence note,
Doct. 1 1. That it is the main and chief duty of a Chri≈øtian in this life, to make this ≈øure to his ≈øoul, that he is effectually called, and eternally elected.
2. From the Manner, how you mu≈øt do this dutie; willingly, or diligently. Note hence,
Doct. 2 2. That Chri≈øtians ought to ≈øet about this duty, of making ≈øure their effectual calling and eternall election, with a great deal of diligence.

3. From the Motive to this dutie; Wherfore Brethren. Wherefore? why, con≈øidering the evil that comes by ≈ølothfulne≈ø≈øe, and by neglect of improving grace, therefore give diligence. The Ob≈øervation hence is,
Doct. 3 3. That ≈øeeing much hurt comes by ≈ølothfulne≈ø≈øe in not improving grace, this ≈øhould ≈øtrongly oblige Chri≈øtians to be the more diligent in all matters of Religion.
4. From the Compari≈øon of this dutie with others: Wherefore the rather, Brethren; i.e. rather then doe any thing, do this, to make your calling and election ≈øure: Hence Note,
Doct. 4 4. That of all imployments in the world,you ≈øhould rather imploy your ≈øelves with diligence in making ≈øure of heaven: To make ≈øure that you are effectually called, and eternally elected.
La≈øtly, From the Compellation of Peter; Wherefore, Brethren: Note,

Doct. 5 5. That when we would fa≈øten Exhortations upon others to duty, we ≈øhould labour to expre≈ø≈øe to them abundance of Affection. Here Peter, when he would urge the Jews to a dutie, in≈øinuates into them by a loving expre≈ø≈øion, calling them Brethren; Wherefore Brethren, give diligence to make your calling and election ≈øure.

But I ≈øhould both confound your memorie, and cro≈ø≈øe my u≈øuall Method, ≈øhould I ≈øpeak of the≈øe five Doctrines thus drawn forth; I had rather then thus mangle the Text, give you the Scope and Sub≈øtance thereof in fewer Doctrines. You may be plea≈øed therefore in dividing the words, to draw them into two parts.
1. A dutie generally pre≈ø≈ø'd, and that in the≈øe words, Give diligence.
2. The particulars wherein our diligence mu≈øt be conver≈øant, expre≈ø≈ø'd: And that in two things. Fir≈øt, In making your calling ≈øure. Secondly, In making your election ≈øure.
From the words thus divided, wil ari≈øe two Points of Doctrine.
Fir≈øt, From the dutie pre≈ø≈ø'd, Give diligence, Note,
Doct. 1 I. That in all matters of ≈øoul concernment, Chri≈øtians ought to put forth a great deal of diligence.
Secondly, From the particulars wherein this dutie of Diligence is to be conver≈øant; that is, in making your Calling and Election ≈øure. Hence ob≈øerve,

Doct. 2 II. That the great diligence of a Chri≈øtian ought chiefly to be imployed about this, to make ≈øure to his ≈øoul, that he is effectually called, and eternally elected. The≈øe are the two Points I ≈øhall draw from the≈øe words.

I begin with the fir≈øt, That in all matters of ≈øoul concernment, Chri≈øtians ought to put forth a great deal of diligence. In the fifth ver≈øe it is ≈øaid likewi≈øe, Give all diligence: as if all your chief endeavours ≈øhould be about the concernments of your ≈øoul.
In the managing of this Point, I ≈øhall lay down the Demon≈øtrations of it; then the Rea≈øons; then Apply it.

Fir≈øt, For the Demon≈øtrations of it: It appears that in all Soul concernments you ≈øhould put forth a great deal of diligence, by tho≈øe Re≈øemblances that the work belonging to the ≈øalvation of the ≈øould is compared to in Scripture. As

1. Sometimes the work of Chri≈øtianity in ≈øaving the ≈øoul is compared to a race: Heb. 12.2. Let us lay a≈øide every weight, and run with patience the race that is ≈øet before us. So 1 Cor. 9.24, 25. When you walk in your Gardens or Galleries, you take no pains; but when you run a race, you labour and ≈øtrive hard, and put forth all your ≈øtrength to attain the end. Why (Beloved) matters about the Soul, they are compared to the running of a race; to ≈øhew, what labours and endeavours you mu≈øt put forth in all imployments of the Soul.

2. It is compared to wre≈øtling, Eph. 6.12. We wre≈øtle not again≈øt fle≈øh and bloud, but again≈øt Principalities and Powers. And ≈øo 2 Tim. 2.5. An allu≈øion to the Olympick games, and publick pa≈øtimes, when men wre≈øtled before the common multitude, wherein they put forth all their ≈øtrength and skill to throw each other down: To note, that Chri≈øtianity is
no ≈ølight work, but a wre≈øtling work, wherein a great deal of diligence and labour is to be put forth.

3. It is expre≈ø≈øed in Scripture by fighting a Battel; 2 Timoth. 4.7. We have fought a good fight. And, As good Souldiers you have endured hardne≈ø≈øe, 2 Tim. 2.3. Now when men are fighting for their lives, what care, and what labour, and what diligence do they put forth to ≈øave them≈øelves? And the work of Chri≈øtianity in the concernments of the Soul is ≈øet forth by this re≈øemblance.

4. It is compared to one being in an Agonie; Luke 13. ver. 24. Strive to enter in at the ≈øtrait gate; The word in the Greek is „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Strive, till you are in an Agonie, as Chri≈øt was: Chri≈øt was in an agonie in the Garden, when he ≈øweat drops of bloud; So ≈øaith Luke, Strive, and Strive, and ≈øtrive till you are in an agonie, that you ≈øweat bloud again in the work of your ≈øouls. Rea≈ø. 6 6. Becau≈øe the more diligent thou art, the le≈øs bu≈øie and operative will the motions of ≈øin and ≈øugge≈øtions of Satan be in thy Spirit.

Rea≈ø. 7 7. div.head: SERMON II.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p: HAving in the morning fini≈øh'd the Doctrinal part of this general Point, I ≈øhall now only make a ≈øhort U≈øe, and then pa≈øs to the particulars wherein you ≈øhould be diligent.

∆≤≈øe 1 1 Now, Is this true, That in all matters of ≈øoul concernment, you mu≈øt put forth a great deal of diligence? Then fir≈øt in applying this Doctrine, I mu≈øt proceed by way of Caution: and I ≈øhal lay down four Cautions, that you may not run into any mi≈øtakes about this Point.

Caut. 1 Fir≈øt, That though God cals for a great deal of diligence at your hands, in the matters of your ≈øouls, yet this doth no way pre≈øuppo≈øe, as if you could draw out, or put forth this diligence, by your own native power; but that God that commands you ≈øtrength, that God mu≈øt give you ≈øtrength to do what he commands. P≈øal. 68.28. Thy God hath commanded thy ≈øtrength: What then? can a man
therefore put forth his own ≈øtrength? No, but the prayer follows; ≈øtrengthen O God, that which thou commande≈øt us. Implying, that though God did command their ≈øtrength, they could not put it out by their own power; but they would make a praier to back the Command: Lord thou command≈øt us to be ≈øtrong, Lord, ≈øtrengthen that which thou commande≈øt. So that though God call for your diligence, and call for your ≈øtrength; yet cannot you put forth any ≈øtrength by your own power. Au≈øtine upon this Con≈øideration hath this pa≈ø≈øage: when I have a will, ≈øaith he, to do good, I have not a power; and when I have power, I have not a will; and herein I ≈øee my own weakne≈ø≈øe, and that I mu≈øt be beholding to Chri≈øt for ≈øtrength. You can as well carrie on the work of Creation, as the work of Conver≈øion by your own ≈øtrength. You can as well conquer a world of armed men alone, as conquer one Sugge≈øtion of the Divel by your own power. Though God doth call for your obedience, and to put forth your diligence, yet this ≈øuppo≈øeth not, as if you could do this by your own ≈øtrength; but that God that Commands you diligence, that God mu≈øt ≈øtir it up in you.

Cauti. 2 2. When God calls for your diligence in matters of ≈øoul Concernment, take this Caution; that you do not di≈øcharge your duty in expre≈ø≈øing a great deal of zeal and diligence in matters of your ≈øoul, unle≈ø≈øe you do it in a right manner, and to a right end. People think, if they can be diligent in hearing, and diligent in reading, and diligent in praying, and in receiving Sacraments; that then, they di≈øcharge their dutie, and an≈øwer the Command of my text, to be diligent. No Beloved, you do not an≈øwer your dutie to God in expre≈ø≈øing diligence in that which is materially good, unle≈ø≈øe you do it in a right manner, and to a right end. You have an in≈øtance in Jehu: 2. Kings 10. He was a marvellous indu≈øtrious man in many good matters concerning the wor≈øhip of God: at one time he kild the wor≈øhippers of Baal, at another time he puld down the hou≈øes where they wor≈øhipped, and broke the graven Images in pieces. At
another time he calls out to Jehonadab, to ≈øee his zeal for the Lord of Ho≈øts. Wonderfull diligent! and yet all this was not done in a good manner, nor to a right end. Not in a good manner, becau≈øe it was but done by halfs, not throughly; for though he de≈øtroyed the Images of Baal, yet he wor≈øhipt the Idols at Bethel. And then not to a right end, becau≈øe he did not ≈øhew this zeal and indu≈øtry out of any ≈øupreme reference to Gods glory, but only out of a politick end; to e≈øtabli≈øh him≈øelf in his kingdom, 2 Kings 10.31. So that you may put forth ≈øuch diligence in reading, and hearing, and in receiving, and the like; and yet, if not done in a right manner, and to a right end, you doe not perform the dutie of my Text. For take this as a Rule in Divinitie, that when God commands a dutie, all the circum≈øtances included in the dutie mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, or el≈øe that dutie is not done aright. As when you pray, you mu≈øt not leave out one circum≈øtance or qualitie required in a prayer, if ≈øo, God will not accept your prayer. So here, God commands your diligence, if you are not diligent in a right manner, and to a right end, your diligence is not right.

Caut. 3 3. Though you put forth never ≈øo much diligence in the matters of your ≈øoul, all tho≈øe acts you do, are none or them meritorious: you do not get heaven for praying, nor get heaven for reading, nor get heaven for hearing, though haply you get not heaven without it. Cau≈øae ≈øine quibus non. Good works, they may be cau≈øes of Salvation in this ≈øen≈øe, Cau≈øes without which you cannot be ≈øaved; but all your obedience, and all your diligence are no cau≈øes for which you are ≈øaved, or which may any way move God to ≈øave you. So that though you are never ≈øo diligent, this diligence is not meritorious at all: Why? Becau≈øe to make it meritorious, ≈øay Divines, three things mu≈øt concur; Fir≈øt, The thing mu≈øt be done freely, not as a debt. Secondly, It mu≈øt be done with a mans own native and proper ≈øtrength, and not a horrowed power. Thirdly, It mu≈øt be done perfectly. And therefore Divines ≈øay, (and that upon good rea≈øon too) That all our obedience, and all our actings in the wayes of grace cannot be meritorious: Why?

Becau≈øe (Fir≈øt) We do them not as a free gift, but as a due debt: we owe God this diligence, and owe him this dutie; and therefore cannot merit, becau≈øe we onely pay God his due. If you lend a man money, will you thank and reward him to pay you your own? No: it is your due, he ought to repay you. All duties in matters of the ≈øoul are Gods due, of right belonging to him, and therefore cannot be meritorious.

Secondly, This diligence, could you put it forth by your own ≈øtrength, you had ≈øomewhat wherein to boa≈øt; but all your diligence is put forth by a borrowed ≈øtrength, by a ≈øtrength derived from Je≈øus Chri≈øt, by a ≈øtrength from the Covenant of grace; it is thence you fetch power to perform all acts of obedience, and ≈øpiritual diligence.

Thirdly, It cannot merit, becau≈øe it is not perfect: nay, you are ≈øo far from meriting by your obedience, that you merit nothing but hell for the defects in your obedience, and the imperfections that are remaining in your be≈øt ≈øervices.

Caut. 4 4. Take this Caution, That though all the diligence you can put forth cannot be meritorious for God to ≈øave you; yet take this for truth, that the more you abound in ≈øpiritual indu≈øtrie in the matters of the Soul, the more likely you are to receive fuller income of joy, and fuller increa≈øe of grace in your ≈øouls: To him that hath ≈øhall be given, and it ≈øhall be given him much more abundantly: That is, to him that hath improved his graces, and u≈øed them wel, they ≈øhall be given more abundantly: Thou ha≈øt been faithful in a little, thou ≈øhalt be ruler over much. The more you act, and the more diligent you are in the matters of your ≈øoul, the more likely you are to be eminent and increa≈øing in grace above others. It is a note that an Author hath upon the Apo≈øtle Paul. Pual was the mo≈øt eminent of all the Apo≈øtles; no Apo≈øtle like Paul, none out≈øtript him. Now Divines ask the rea≈øon, why Paul ≈øhould be more eminent then the re≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, who ≈øaw Chri≈øt in the fle≈øh; whereas Paul ≈øaw him onely in a vi≈øion, and
no where el≈øe; yet Paul was more eminent then any other Apo≈øtle? and they give this rea≈øon: Paul was in labours more abundant; Paul was more indu≈øtrious, putting out his gifts and graces, and God did ble≈ø≈øe that indu≈øtry with a fuller increa≈øe of the graces of Gods Spirit then others had: So that, though God gives us not heaven for our growth in grace; yet ordinarily God intails a greater mea≈øure and increa≈øe of gifts upon the wel u≈øing of them while we are in the world: Open your mouthes wide, and God will fill them. div.p: Beloved, This is a very material Point I am now upon, e≈øpecially in this deceitful age, wherein men plunge them≈øelves into a gulph of pre≈øumption, wherein many times men take faith upon tru≈øt, and Chri≈øt upon tru≈øt. Why Beloved, have you ever ≈øeen this? did you ever ≈øee that mi≈øery that ≈øin brought upon you? that ≈øin did deve≈øt you of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, did rob you of your God, bani≈øh you from his pre≈øence, intitle you to hell and make you objects of his wrath? 3. God puts the ≈øoul into a kind of ≈øpirituall a≈øtoni≈øhment, that the poor ≈øinner doth not know where to goe, what cour≈øe to take, which way to turn, how he may get pardon for his ≈øin, and recoverie from his mi≈øerie. They were even in a maze, the word wrought upon them, and they ≈øaw Je≈øus Chri≈øt crucified to be their ≈øin; and now they crie out in great a≈øtoni≈øhment, Men and Brethren, what ≈øhall we do to be ≈øaved? When God effectually calls a man, he will leave him a little to him≈øelf, that he knows not which way in the world to turn him. Now when I ≈øpeak of ≈øpiritual A≈øtoni≈øhment, mi≈øtake me not; for Fir≈øt, I pre≈øs not ≈øuch a mea≈øure of Humiliation, nor ≈øuch a mea≈øure of trouble of mind, how great it mu≈øt be; Nor Secondly do I pre≈øs the duration of it; how long it mu≈øt be; that you mu≈øt be ≈øo long and ≈øo long. Indeed, we read of Lydia, that her heart was opened, and ≈øhe never troubled nor a≈øtoni≈øht; and God ≈øometimes works thus in an extraordinarie way: but I pre≈øs this, that ordinarily, its Gods Method in ≈øome mea≈øure or other, at ≈øome time or other, to put his people into ≈øuch a plunge, that they ≈øhall not know which way in the world to turne them≈øelves. And ≈øo were tho≈øe 3000 Acts 2. They could not tell what they ≈øhould do to be ≈øaved.

And here further, if you ask me, With whom doth God
mo≈øt of all take this cour≈øe, to put them into ≈øuch ≈øpirituall amazement; to put them into horror and terror about their everla≈øting e≈øtate? I An≈øwer, fir≈øt, Tho≈øe that have liv'd in a cour≈øe of profanene≈øs before Conver≈øion; let them look to it: if thou ha≈øt been a knottie and ≈øtout-hearted ≈øinner again≈øt God, God mu≈øt give thee many a blow before he can hammer thee to his own will. You that have been guiltie of Drunkenne≈øs, and guiltie of Adultery, or guiltie of Sabbath-breaking in a gro≈øs and licencious way, that have made this world a ≈øtage to act wickedne≈ø≈øe upon, look to it; boa≈øt not of your Calling: if God hath not brought you in this way, you have ground to ≈øu≈øpect, you are not yet call'd. They that before Conver≈øion were loo≈øe in their lives, if they find not this ≈øpirituall amazement, it is not likely they are call'd. And therefore I verily ≈øu≈øpect your Call, that can jump out of a cour≈øe of Profanene≈ø≈øe, into a cour≈øe of Profe≈ø≈øion; that can jump from a cour≈øe of Malignitie to delight to hear Sermons, and love Mini≈øters. You that have been oppo≈øers of godline≈øs, if you do not ≈øhew an eminent work in your Conver≈øion, I greatly ≈øu≈øpect, whether you are converted or no: becau≈øe it is Gods u≈øuall Method, if men have been men of gro≈øs lives before calling, to bring them to great a≈øtoni≈øhment when they are called.

2. You that have often with≈øtood, and ≈øtill with≈øtand Gods call; that Sermon after Sermon, and invitation after invitation would not gain upon you; Do you look about you; God will give you many a blow, God will ≈øend you many a ≈øad houre, before he brings you to your peace.

3. Tho≈øe that have often ≈øinn'd again≈øt Con≈øcience, that do as it were lay Con≈øcience wa≈øt; that are prodigall of ≈øinning, not caring for ≈øinning again≈øt never ≈øo much light; and never ≈øo much conviction. Beloved, you ≈øhall not have ≈øo ea≈øie a coming to heaven: God wil fir≈øt lay many ≈øtroaks upon you, and draw heavie groans from you. David ≈øaith, By rea≈øon of thy terrors I am afraid, and my bone are dried up: You are ≈øubject to mo≈øt horror and a≈øtoni≈øhment,
that do ≈øin again≈øt Con≈øcience. Again,

4. When God hath done thus, made you ≈øee the aggravated nature of ≈øin, ≈øhewn you your mi≈øery by rea≈øon of ≈øin, and brought you into ≈øuch a condition that you cannot tell how to be ≈øaved; then 4. this is Gods Method, to take you off from your own bottome, beat you off from re≈øting in duties, and beat you off from dependance upon graces, and beat you off from every thing in your ≈øelves. This was Gods work in Paul, Phil. 3.9, 10. I was, ≈øaith Paul, Circumci≈øed the 8th day, of the ≈øtock of I≈ørael, of the Tribe of Benjamin, an Hebrew of the Hebrews; that is, my father and mother were Hebrews: what then? and I was, touching the Law, blamele≈øs. Mark, he was ≈øo ≈øtanding upon his own legs, upon his own bottome; that he thought him≈øelf a holy man, a man blamele≈øs touching the Law. But now, ≈øaith he, what things were gain to me, I count lo≈øs for Chri≈øt; yea doubtle≈ø≈øe, I count all things lo≈øt, that I might be found in Chri≈øt, not having my own righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. Here Paul before Conver≈øion depended upon his holy living, and hone≈øt dealing; but now I am converted, and ≈øee my folly; now I de≈øire to be found in Chri≈øt, not having mine own righteou≈øne≈øs. See how God did unbottome Paul from any goodne≈øs in him≈øelf, to make him re≈øt upon Je≈øus Chri≈øt: and this is Gods work with thee; he will unbottome thee from thy ≈øelf, and make thee ≈øee thou can≈øt not be thine own Saviour.

5. After he hath unbottom'd thee from thy ≈øelf, he puts thee upon earne≈øt longings and looking after Je≈øus Chri≈øt. When the poor ≈øoul hath ran≈øack'd duties, and gone to this Mini≈øter, and the other Mini≈øter, to be ≈øatisfied; and he ≈øees duties cannot help him, and prayer will not help him; now he thinks, I ≈øee none but Chri≈øt to lay my head upon: and I ≈øee none but a Chri≈øt I mu≈øt make my recour≈øe unto: And now he is ≈øo longing after Chri≈øt, that if all the ≈øtones in the ≈øtreets were gold, and all the building of his hou≈øe were diamond, and all his garments be≈øpangled with pear ‚Ä¢ e; none of the≈øe ≈øhould interrupt, or ≈øtay him from running after Je≈øus Chri≈øt; and this, as I may ≈øay, is Gods ≈øecond

6. It is Gods method after all this, to make them find abundance of contentment, and acquie≈øcence in Je≈øus Chri≈øt; that they may have occa≈øion to ≈øay, I ≈øee I have laid my help upon one that is mightie; I ≈øee I have picht upon him, that is both able and willing to do me good. 2 The≈ø. 2.16. hath given us everla≈øting con≈øolation, and good hope through grace. div.head: SERMON III.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p:
HAving fini≈øht the fir≈øt part of the di≈øcoverie, in relation to the Method God takes with tho≈øe whom he doth effectually call. I now proceed to the ≈øecond way of di≈øcoverie, and that is by tho≈øe ≈øaving
Concomitants, that doe and will accompanie a ≈øoul, that is effectually call'd: and the≈øe ≈øaving effects, I ≈øhall reduce under eight heads.

Fir≈øt, A man effectually call'd by Chri≈øt, he doth unfainedly love the word of God, and the Mini≈øter that preached that word that God did u≈øe as an in≈øtrument of his call. Fir≈øt, I ≈øay, he will love the word, John 8.47. He that is of God, (that is, he that is call'd by God) heareth Gods word, therefore you are not of God, becau≈øe you heare not his word. There the Scripture tels us, that they who are of God, effectually called by him, they heare his word with abundance of delight; and abundance of joy and love. So 1 John 4, 5, 6. He that is of God heareth us, he that is not of God heareth not us. And therefore David, when he would evidence a work of God upon his heart, P≈øal. 119.14. Thy word, ≈øaith he, is as great riches to me. And as if he did not value riches comparable to the word, ver≈ø. 72. I love thy word above thou≈øands of gold, and ≈øilver. Beloved, if you are converted and called by Je≈øus Chri≈øt, you will love the Word of God, that was an in≈øtrument of your Call. Wherfore, all you that ≈øpurn again≈øt the Go≈øpel, that cannot endure to have the word come with power upon your con≈øciences; all you that are weary of Ordinances, and finde no more ≈øavour in an Ordinance of God, then (as Job ≈øaith) there is ta≈øte in the white of an egg; this is an argument you are not yet called. What's the rea≈øon one man will ri≈øe early, go far, take pains, and many times neglect his own lawfull affairs, and all to enjoy the Word: when another man will goe by the Church-door, and haply go to a Tavern, and will not go to hear the Word at all? What's the rea≈øon? One is call'd by the Word, and the other not: one is called by the Word, and therefore loves it; another is not called, and that makes him neglect it.

2. He doth not onely love the word, but the Mini≈øter that by preaching the word was an in≈øtrument of his conver≈øion. And therefore it is ob≈øervable which ≈øome Divines note, That of all men that we read of in Scripture, there
was no man did love Paul ≈øo much as Timothie: For I have no man like minded, ≈øaith Paul, Phil. 2.22. No man that did ≈øo naturally care for him, and for the Church of God, as he; For as a ≈øon with his father, hath hee ≈øerved me. And what's the rea≈øon? Why, Paul was the in≈øtrument of Timothy's Conver≈øion, and Timothy being a Mini≈øter, and come to a great pitch in grace, hee thought that of all Arguments in the world, that ≈øhould indear him to love Paul, becau≈øe Paul was the Mini≈øter that did convert him: therefore he calls him (1 Tim. 1.2.) Timothy his beloved ≈øon in the faith. And hence it is, that when the Apo≈øtle would draw love from the Corinthians to him≈øelf, and the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt that were the means of their calling, hee urgeth it upon this ground, that they were the means that did beget them to Chri≈øt Je≈øus, 1 Cor. 4. ver. 1. compared with ver. 15, 16. Let a man ≈øo account of us, as of the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, and as Stewards of the my≈øteries of God. Why ≈øhould men ≈øo account of them? For (ver. 15.) though you have ten thou≈øand In≈øtructors, yet have you not many Fathers; for in Chri≈øt Je≈øus I have begotten you through the Go≈øpel. Hereby he would draw out their love to him, becau≈øe he was the in≈øtrument that did fir≈øt convert them. Now then, put the≈øe two together: A man that is effectually called, he doth both love the Word of Chri≈øt, that was an in≈øtrument of his calling; and the Mini≈øter that preach'd that word, which was the means by which he was called: and try your ≈øelves by the≈øe. Many of you haply have ≈øome good wrought (as you think) upon you, and ≈øome change in you; but truly let me tell you this, if you are per≈øons that are out of love with the Word, if you are out of love with tho≈øe Mini≈øters God made in≈øtrumental to convert you; you have ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect your calling; for you ≈øee thorowout the whole cour≈øe of Scripture, their hearts did cleave with love to them that called them: And therefore they that can ≈ølight and contemn tho≈øe Mini≈øters by who≈øe mini≈øtry they were brought home to Je≈øus Chri≈øt, they have ju≈øt cau≈øe of jealou≈øie to ≈øu≈øpect their Call. Again,

2. If God hath effectually called you, he will by his Spirit bring you out of a ≈øtate of ignorance and darkne≈ø≈øe, and give you ≈øome mea≈øure of knowledg, to be acquainted both with the my≈øteries of God and Chri≈øt, and the ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe of your ≈øelves, more then ever you were before. This the Apo≈øtle Peter intimates, 1 Pet. 2. ver. 9. You are a cho≈øen generation, a royall Prie≈øthood, a peculiar people, that you may ≈øhew forth the prai≈øes of him, who hath called you out of darkne≈ø≈øe into his marvellous light: i. e. out of ignorance into a great mea≈øure of knowledg. And it is called a marvellous light, 1. Becau≈øe it is marvellous if you compare that knowledg you ≈øhall have under the Go≈øpel, with what men had under the Law. 2. It is marvellous, becau≈øe men are a≈øtoni≈øh'd, that they ≈øhould, after ≈øo long a night of ignorance, come to ≈øo great a mea≈øure of knowledg. 3. It is called marvell us, becau≈øe it is ≈øo contrary to that condition they were formerly in: As if a man that hath lain long in a dark dungeon, ≈øhould be ≈øuddenly called into a glorious Palace, the Palace would ≈øeem more glorious, becau≈øe it is ≈øo contrary to the dark Pri≈øon: So this work of God when he calls you, it is called marvellous light, becau≈øe it is ≈øo contrary to the condition you were in before your calling. I≈øa. 30.26. Acts 26.18. He hath ≈øent his word to call you from darkne≈ø≈øe to light, and from the power of Sathan to God. 4. It is a marvellous light, becau≈øe ≈øuch as none but the Mediator could procure it, I≈øa. 42.6, 7. I will give thee for a light to the gentiles. 5. It is a marvellous light, becau≈øe a light that ≈øhines out of darkne≈ø≈øe, 2 Cor. 4.6. God that commanded the light to ≈øhine out of darkne≈ø≈øe. 6. It is a marvellous light becau≈øe it hath more force then any other light: 'tis called the light of life, Joh. 8.12.

Now this call from darkne≈ø≈øe to light hath two Branches: 1. A man ≈øhall have more light, to have more acquaintance with, and more clearne≈ø≈øe in the my≈øteries of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: And 2. more light to know the ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe of him≈øelf.

Fir≈øt, He ≈øhall have more light to know the my≈øteries of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: And hence it is that Paul tels us, Gal. 1.16.
It plea≈øed God to call me by his grace, and to reveal his Son in me; implying, that where God by his grace doth call a ≈øinner, he doth reveal his Son unto him. Wherefore, Beloved, if Je≈øus Chri≈øt be not made known to your ≈øouls, if you have no competent mea≈øure of the knowledg of Chri≈øt; you may be under this conviction, that you are not yet called by Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Nay further, he doth not onely call you unto this light, to manife≈øt Je≈øus Chri≈øt to you in ≈øome dim way; but you ≈øhall have a clear light: 2 Cor. 4.6. For God who commanded light to ≈øhine out of darkne≈ø≈øe, hath ≈øhined in our hearts (not in a dim, but ≈øhining light) to give us the light of the knowledg of the glory of God in the face of Je≈øus Chri≈øt: that is, you have a cleer light to know God in the face of Chri≈øt; you cannot know God in him≈øelf, but in the per≈øon of Chri≈øt you ≈øhall have light to know him. This therefore is the fir≈øt Branch, That God will put a light into thy ≈øoul, whereby thou ≈øhalt have a clear knowledg of the things appertaining to Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Again Secondly, This light ≈øhall not onely reveal Chri≈øt to thee; but this light ≈øhall al≈øo reveal thy Self to thee, the ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe of thy ≈øelf. It is ob≈øervable of Paul, that before his calling, he was after the law blamele≈ø≈øe; he thought him≈øelf to be a faultle≈ø≈øe man; but when the word called him, then he cryes out, I ≈øee ≈øin to be exceeding ≈øinfull: then he ≈øaw ≈øin to be ≈øin, and him≈øelf to be a vile and wretched man. And therefore, Beloved, any of you that have not this marvellous light in your ≈øouls, neither to know God, nor know Je≈øus Chri≈øt, nor the matters appertaining to him, nor to know the ≈øinfulne≈ø≈øe of your own hearts; take it from God, you are not effectually called: either the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages in Scripture mu≈øt be ra≈øed out, or el≈øe your calling mu≈øt not be ≈øound; and therefore take heed: I would fain make my Mini≈øtrie ≈øearching, that hypocrites may not lie lurking under it. You would be better Chri≈øtians, if you were better acquainted with all that un≈øoundne≈ø≈øe, and that wretchedne≈ø≈øe of heart that is in you; and therefore (I intreat you) look about you: Though I would have
no godly man di≈øcouraged by this that is ≈øpoken; but that you that are not yet called, might have your hearts a little ≈øtaggered by what is and will be ≈øaid.

3. A man effectually called is ca≈øt out of him≈øelf, and cleaves to, and clo≈øeth with Je≈øus Chri≈øt, with more complacencie and contentment, then ever he could do in all his life before. John 6.45. Hee that hath heard and learned of the father, ≈øhall come unto me; he doth not ≈øay, all they that hear of the father: many men do heare the word, but never clo≈øe in with Chri≈øt; but all they that have heard, and by hearing have learnt, and are called, come unto mee, and clo≈øe in with me, and cleave to me, and take content and delight in me. Beloved, there are many that hear the word, yet never go out of them≈øelves, and never clo≈øe in with Chri≈øt: yea but all they that heare and learne, that hear and are called by hearing, they all come in to Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Wherefore all you, that in hearing cannot find your hearts in love with Chri≈øt, cannot find your hearts to clo≈øe in with Chri≈øt, and believe in Chri≈øt; you have ju≈øt cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect your Call, that your calling is not effectual. 1 Cor. 1.24. The Apo≈øtle tels you, there were other men counted Chri≈øt fooli≈øhne≈ø≈øe; but to you that are called, Chri≈øt is the power and wi≈øedome of God: that is, you do acknowledg, and you do conceive of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, that he hath as much power as God hath in him, and as much wi≈øedome as God hath in him; and you clo≈øe in with Chri≈øt for that end, when other men think Chri≈øt to be fooli≈øh, and Chri≈øt weak; men uncall'd, they have low thoughts of Chri≈øt; but to you that are call'd, Chri≈øt is the power and wi≈øedome of God: You will have high thoughts of Je≈øus Chri≈øt if you are effectually called.

4. That man that is effectually called, he ≈øhall be inabled by the ≈øpirit of Chri≈øt to call upon God, 1. Cor. 1.2. To all in Corinth called to be Saints, with all that call upon the name of the Lord. There the Apo≈øtle joynes called to be Saints, with this phra≈øe, to call upon God; to ≈øhew, that whoever is effectually called to be a Saint, that man ≈øhall be inabled by

Hence ye read, Acts 9.11. when Ananias doubted whether Paul was truely call'd or no, and Je≈øus Chri≈øt would convince Ananias that he was truely call'd; what means doth he u≈øe? ver≈øe 11. do not ≈øu≈øpect him, but ari≈øe ≈øaith Chri≈øt, and goe to him into the ≈øtreet, called Straight; and enquire at the hou≈øe of Judas for one Saul of Tar≈øus, for behold he prayeth. If he were not call'd, he would never goe to God in ≈øuch a cordiall way, and humble his ≈øoul before God for his by pa≈øt failings; and beg ≈øtrength for time to come, and labour to have his peace made with me. Go to him, for behold he prayeth: and therefore all you that have not a ≈øpirit in any mea≈øure to call upon God, and to powr forth your reque≈øts in a ≈øolemn prayer; you have ju≈øt cau≈øe of jealou≈øie to ≈øu≈øpect your Call.

5. If you are effectually call'd, God hath wrought in your ≈øouls, an utter dete≈øtation and loathing of all the evils that in the former part of your lives before you calling your have committed and were guilty of. Ho≈ø. 14.8. Ephraim ≈øhall ≈øay, what have I any more to doe with Idols? The interrogation imports a vehement dete≈øtation of them, and indignation again≈øt them. 2 Cor. 7.11. the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaks there of repentance, (the ≈øame with calling) when men come to have the work of grace in their hearts; and this is a branch of it; that godly ≈øorrow cau≈øeth care, and cau≈øeth fear, and cau≈øeth indignation: that is, if any man be a repenting man, and a converted man; this conver≈øion will cau≈øe indignation: that is, he will be even mad with him≈øelf, and angry with him≈øelf, that he ≈øhould be ≈øo vile a wretch before conver≈øion, as he hath been. Thus was Paul, hee ≈øpeaks with indignation again≈øt the ≈øins he was guilty of before his calling; I have been a per≈øecutor, I have hal'd the Saints into pri≈øon; Nay, ≈øaith hee, I was even mad again≈øt the Church. Beloved, you will count your ≈øins to be madne≈ø≈øe, and count them to be greatly aggravated, that were committed before God call'd you. An≈øelm ≈øaid to his body, I'le tame thee, O unruly bea≈øt, with fa≈øting
and praier. We read of one that bit off his tongue in indignation, that therewith he had denied Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Another Martyr put that hand fir≈øt into the fire, with which he had ≈øub≈øcribed a recantation; ≈øaying, Burn thou, O hand, that did≈øt ≈øub≈øcribe to that which might have made me burn both body and ≈øoul in hell. And therefore you that have no loathing thoughts again≈øt pa≈øt deceit, and pa≈øt drunkenne≈ø≈øe, and pa≈øt ≈øwearing, and your pa≈øt evils; ≈øu≈øpect your calling: You that do not abhor the thoughts of your former evils, your wonted pride, and wonted covetou≈øne≈ø≈øe; if you cannot looke with indignation again≈øt the≈øe, you have great cau≈øe to ≈øu≈øpect your call: For if God have call'd you, he will make you even angry with your ≈øelves, that ever you have been ≈øo vile as you have been. And that you may under≈øtand the an≈øwer hereto, I mu≈øt lay down this di≈øtinction; That there is a twofold calling of Chri≈øt:

∆≤≈øe 1 Fir≈øt, an U≈øe of Condemnation to wicked men, that have often re≈øi≈øted the ≈øignificative call of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Secondly, Suppo≈øe the Devil could a≈ø≈øure you, you ≈øhould live till old age; yet take this con≈øideration, that in putting off your calling, and the work of conver≈øion from your youth, this may ≈øo provoke God, that he may harden your hearts in your old dayes, that you ≈øhall have no heart to think of, and imbrace the call and invitation of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. div.head: SERMON VI.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p: THe Doctrine I am yet upon, is this. That Chri≈øtians ought to put forth a great deal of diligence, to make this ≈øure to their ≈øouls, that they are effectually called by Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Fir≈øt, Whereas you ≈øay, they are melancholy and ≈øad, that are called by Chri≈øt to a profe≈ø≈øion of his waies; I would an≈øwer thus, That they of all people in the world, have mo≈øt cau≈øe of mirth and gladnes, and they are the mo≈øt truly joyful people in the world. And la≈øtly, Though you ≈øee ≈øome men ≈øad and melancholy, yet think not ill of the waies of God; becau≈øe, this way of all other, doth mo≈øt invite to joy and gladne≈øs in the Lord. In the profe≈ø≈øion and following of Chri≈øt, it is the intendment of Chri≈øt to give you more joy, then ever you had before; there is no ≈øuch cau≈øe therefore to entertain a prejudice by the Divels temptation again≈øt the waies of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, when he cals you to profe≈ø≈øe his Go≈øpel. There is a third ca≈øe touching men uncalled, and that is, What delu≈øions doth the Divell deceive hypocrites by, to make them nouri≈øh pre≈øumptuous per≈øwa≈øions that they are effectually called when they are not? Delu≈ø. 1. The Divel may delude men by this, becau≈øe they do delight to hear the word preacht, therefore the Divel would egg on this per≈øwa≈øion, ≈øurely your delighting to hear the word, and your following of Sermons, this mu≈øt needs be an evidence of your effectual calling. 1. Au≈øtin that he was converted not by hearing a Sermon, but by opening the Bible, and reading that place. Rom 13.13. Let us walk hone≈øtly as in the day time, not in rioting and drunkenne≈ø≈øe, not in chambering and wantonne≈ø≈øe: and the reading of this ver≈øe wrought upon him. I have read of Cyprian, that he was converted by reading the Prophecie of Jonas, hearing of Gods mercy to ≈øave ≈øuch a wicked people, and of Gods mercy to Jonas, when he was in ≈øo petti≈øh a mood as to be angry with God. I have known likewi≈øe another famous Mini≈øter, that going by a Book-binders ≈øhop, he was converted by reading a Sermon of Repentance that co≈øt but two pence; & hath bin a famous Mini≈øter ≈øince for the conver≈øion of many hundreds to Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Junius was converted by reading the fir≈øt of John; ≈øo the Eunuch was converted by reading I≈øa. 53.7. Beloved, God is not bound up to any one way in ≈øaving man; He that wrought upon Au≈øtin by a ver≈øe reading & upon another by a Sermon, he can do ≈øo by thee Reading is an ordinance of God, and God is not bound up, but may u≈øe that as ameans of thy effectual call likewi≈øe.

Thirdly, Yea but, ≈øaith another doubting ≈øoul, Peradventure I was never wrought upon, neither by ≈øeeing godly people among whom I lived, and ob≈øerving their example, nor was I wrought upon by reading good books; but I was fir≈øt wrought upon by hearing ≈øuch a Mini≈øter, that I now ≈øee is run into error; or a Mini≈øter that is grown loo≈øe in his practice (happily in the≈øe pre≈øent times gone to joyne with the enemy again≈øt the Kingdom,) and become a wicked and vile liver; and the Mini≈øter being bad that wrought upon me, makes me que≈øtion, whether the work be not an un≈øound and bad work al≈øo, and this gravels many a Chri≈øtian likewi≈øe. To which I an≈øwer briefly,

Fir≈øt, That ≈øuppo≈øe the Mini≈øter were bad that wrought upon thee, yet the badne≈ø≈øe of the Mini≈øter is no ju≈øt ground
of making us ≈øu≈øpect our calling. For then we ≈øhould never be ≈øure of our call. A man may be ≈øure of his own conver≈øion, though a man may not be ≈øure of the conver≈øion, of him by who≈øe means he was called.

Secondly, Again it is clear in Scripture, God may u≈øe Mini≈øters that are wicked them≈øelves to convert others. The Mini≈øters of the ≈øeven Churches of A≈øia, doubtle≈ø≈øe ≈øome of them were bad men; Paul tells you, 1 Cor. 9.27. I keep under my body, le≈øt when I preach to others, I my ≈øelf may be a ca≈øtaway. Intimating, that a man may preach to others, and may be a means to ≈øave others, and yet not be ≈øaved him≈øelf. So 1 Cor. 13.1. Mini≈øters in this ca≈øe may be as Cooks are. A Cook may dre≈ø≈øe many a di≈øh, and let them go through his hands to furni≈øh a large and ≈øtately Table, yet of all the≈øe di≈øhes him≈øelf hardly ta≈øte one; So Mini≈øters, they may dre≈ø≈øe many a di≈øh for their hearers, yet they not lick their fingers, or ta≈øte of this ≈øpiritual food them≈øelves. As in the building of the Ark, there were many men built Noahs Ark, to ≈øave others, that were drowned them≈øelves; ≈øo many men may build an Ark by preaching the Word, and the wayes of God to ≈øave other mens ≈øoules, when they may be drowned them≈øelves. Hence it is the Scripture tells us of Starres that fell from Heaven; many Mini≈øters, that ≈øeemed godly Mini≈øters, like Starres in their Generation, yet they fell, and became wicked and loo≈øe. And I remember Doctor Pembleton a famous Mini≈øter in the dayes of Queen Mary; and a man who≈øe Mini≈øtry had converted many Chri≈øtians, yet at length he him≈øelf turned to be a Papi≈øt. Now the≈øe Chri≈øtians did never mi≈ødoubt or ≈øu≈øpect their conver≈øion, becau≈øe the man that converted them, was a bad man; They might be good people, though he was a bad Mini≈øter: ≈øo that this is no ground in the world; though I confe≈ø≈øe it is not ordinary, that God makes wicked men meanes of conver≈øion, but God ordinarily crowns the Word mo≈øt in the mouth of a godly Mini≈øter, yet ≈øometimes I ≈øay, God may u≈øe a wicked man to be a means to convert ≈øoules. And I would give you the≈øe rea≈øons to prove, that a wicked
man may convert ≈øoules, and that God ties not conver≈øion onely to a godly Mini≈øter. Becau≈øe fir≈øt, the efficacy of the Word doth not depend upon man, but upon Je≈øus Chri≈øt; and Chri≈øt may make u≈øe of whom he plea≈øeth.

Secondly, If only a good man could convert, then this would follow, that we could be as well ≈øure of another mans conver≈øion, as we are of our own; which is a thing mo≈øt untrue. For if only a godly man could convert, then if I were ≈øure of my own conver≈øion, I were as well ≈øure of his conver≈øion that wrought upon me al≈øo; which cannot be, ≈øo that clearly this ≈øhould lay no block in your way, becau≈øe you di≈øcern the Mini≈øter that wrought upon you to be no good man, ≈øeeing conver≈øion is not tied onely to a godly Mini≈øter.

Thirdly, a third ground from whence doubts ari≈øe in called ones, is from ≈øome ≈øeeming defects they apprehend to be in the concomitants that accompany, or in the effects that ≈øhould follow effectual calling: and this makes them fear, that ≈øure they are not effectually called. I will name to you three or four.

Fir≈øt, (≈øaith a doubting Chri≈øtian) I do hear in Scripture what effects will follow, and what will accompany a man effectually called, and I find them not wrought in my ≈øoul. As now fir≈øt. I apprehend that when a man is effectually called, he ≈øhall be inabled by God to call upon him in prayer: I finde in Scripture, 1 Cor. 1.2. That all that are called to be Saints, they ≈øhall call upon the Lord in every place; but alas, wo is me, I do not find this in my ≈øoul. I find I have a dull, dead, li≈øtle≈ø≈øe, unpraying heart all the dayes of my life; and therefore I doubt whether I am effectually called or no. Now to this I ≈øhall lay down three things for an≈øwer.

Fir≈øt, peradventure you judge that you are not enabled to pray, becau≈øe you want expre≈ø≈øions in prayer, though you have affections. Now if you judge your inability to pray, becau≈øe you want expre≈ø≈øions only, you judge ami≈ø≈øe, becau≈øe prayer is to be judged by the affections, not by the expre≈ø≈øions. Expre≈ø≈øions they are but the breath of nature,
a natural voluble tongue may tumble out expre≈ø≈øions; whereas affections in prayer, they are the breath and fruit of the holy Spirit. Therefore do not judge you cannot pray, becau≈øe you have not ≈øuch fluent expre≈ø≈øions as others u≈øe, for the very e≈ø≈øence of a prayer lies in the heart, and therefore it is ≈øaid, when the Spirit of God teacheth men to pray, it teacheth them not only in expre≈ø≈øions, but with ≈øighs and groans that cannot be uttered. Rom. 8.26. When the Spirit moves the heart, and makes you ≈øigh out your reque≈øts, and ≈øorrow out your ≈øupplications, you pray be≈øt of all.

Secondly, you that judge your inability to pray, and therefore think you are not called, becau≈øe you cannot call upon God, I would ≈øay this unto you: That the be≈øt of Gods children have found a great difference in their ≈øpirits in reference to praying duties; the be≈øt of Gods children do not alwayes pray alike. Sometimes the affections of godly men are as ≈øwift in prayer, as the Chariots of Aminadab; otherwhiles they drive as heavily as Pharaohs Chariots when the wheels were off. Sometime the people of God are burning in their affections, hot as fire; otherwhiles they are frozen in their affections, cold as ice. None of Gods people are in their carriage alwayes alike towards God in prayer. P≈øal. 77.4. It is the ≈øpeech of A≈øaph, O Lord, my ≈øpirit is overwhelmed within me, I am ≈øore troubled, I cannot ≈øpeak. The man was ≈øo troubled, he could not ≈øpeak, yet A≈øaph ≈øpake the≈øe words with his mouth; but the meaning is, though A≈øaph was a godly man, yet he was ≈øo overwhelmed with trouble, he could not ≈øpeak to God, he could not call upon God with that inward vigor of ≈øpirit. Though thou maye≈øt ≈øometime call upon God with affection, yet when trouble re≈øts upon thee, thy heart may be out of frame.

Thirdly, many times Gods people are ≈øubject to a ≈øtate of de≈øertion, and abatements in their ≈øpiritual affections, and then they are out of a praying vein; when you loo≈øe affections, the wheels of prayer are knocked off. Many times it falls out with Gods people, that they are even brought into
a langui≈øhing and low condition, they are in ≈øuch a ≈øwoune as if they had neither a principle, nor the actings of ≈øpiritual life. Rev. 3. ver≈øe 2. Strengthen that which remaines, ≈øaith the holy Gho≈øt; that is ready to die. Godly people may bee a dying people, and then the tongue failes, when it is a dying: the people of God may be in a dying condition; though they never die wholly in grace, yet they may be ≈øo weakned in their ≈øpirits, that they cannot poure out their reque≈øts to God as in wonted time. 2 Chron. 17.3. Jeho≈øaphat he walked in the fir≈øt wayes of David his father: implying that Davids fir≈øt wayes were better then his la≈øt. So many men may have their fir≈øt wayes good, yet ≈øometime in the end before they die, they may have much failing, and deadne≈ø≈øe of ≈øpirit upon them.

Fourthly, If a man doth but mourn, that he cannot call upon God, God looks upon that as calling upon him. If you can but ≈øigh out your reque≈øts, and mourn that you cannot mourn, and pray that you might pray; the Lord hears your prayer. This is the mo≈øt melodious mu≈øick you can make in the eares of God. Therefore David ≈øaith, P≈øal. 6.8. The Lord hath heard the voice of my weeping: There is a voice in Teares, as well as in Words. If the Lord ≈øee thee to weep over thine own ≈øtraitne≈ø≈øe, and mourn over thine own deadne≈ø≈øe, the Lord looks upon this with a more plea≈øing eye, then if thou could≈øt poure out the inlargements of thy tongue, with mo≈øt fluent and voluble expre≈ø≈øions.

div.p: THE Doctrine which I am yet upon is this, That Chri≈øtians ought to put forth a great deal of diligence to make this ≈øure to their ≈øouls, that they are effectually called by Je≈øus Chri≈øt. In the pro≈øecution of which I have gone over many particulars, and an≈øwered ≈øome doubts, in re≈øerence to godly men who are effectually called. As fir≈øt, in regard of ≈øome ≈øeeming defects they apprehend to be in the manner of their calling. Secondly, in the means of their calling. And thirdly, (which I am yet upon,) of ≈øome defects they apprehend about the concomitants that accompany tho≈øe that are effectually called, of which I have ≈øpoken onely of one in particular, to wit, that they cannot call upon God in prayer; I now pa≈ø≈øe to the ≈øecond.

Secondly, They apprehend that tho≈øe that are effectually called, they have this to accompany their calling, that they are brought out of a ≈øtate of ignorance into a ≈øtate of knowledge, out of a ≈øtate of darkne≈ø≈øe into a ≈øtate of light; hence they will urge this again≈øt them≈øelves, 1 Pet. 2.9. Ye are to ≈øhew forth the prai≈øes of him, who hath call'd you out of darkne≈ø≈øe into his marvellous light. And Acts 26.18. He ≈øent forth his Word to call them from darkne≈ø≈øe to light, and from the power of Satan unto God. Now ≈øaith the poor ≈øoul, Alas, I do not finde this concomitant to be in my heart, I do not finde this marvellous light the Scripture here ≈øpeaks of, 2 Cor. 4 6. Alas, my heart is
like a dungeon of darkne≈ø≈øe, and like a hou≈øe that hath no inlets, no windows to let in the Sun-≈øhine of the Go≈øpel upon it: and many times this gravelleth many a godly minde. Now to tho≈øe that make this doubt, I ≈øhall onely ≈øpeak two or three things to take it off.

Fir≈øt, to you that make this complaint, I would ≈øay this: that tho≈øe that know mo≈øt, they know but little in the my≈øteries of Chri≈øt; as you are not perfect in other graces, ≈øo you are not here perfect in knowledg; You know but in part, 1 Cor. 13.9. therefore you have no need to be di≈øcouraged at this.

Secondly, and more particularly, you that complain of ignorance; though you are ignorant, and cannot finde that marvellous light ≈øhine in your ≈øouls, which you ex≈øpect, yet if your ignorance have not the≈øe three ill qualities, you may re≈øt confident your ignorance will never prove a damning ≈øinne unto you, but it may be con≈øi≈øtent with your effectual calling; As
Fir≈øt, If you ignorance be not a ≈øtubborne and wilfull ignorance. Secondly, If it be not a ≈øotti≈øh and bruti≈øh ignorance. And thirdly, If it be not a fundamental ignorance.

Fir≈øt, If it be not a ≈øtubborne and wilfull ignorance. Though you are ignorant, yet if you are willing to learn, and know the wayes of God revealed in his Word, ≈øuch an ignorance will never damne you: But when ignorance comes to be wilful, that a man doth not know, and he will not learne; a man is an ignorant man yet he thinks he knows more then all the Preachers can tell him; this is a ≈øad ≈øigne you are not effectually called. Hence you read, Prov. 1.22. How long, ye ≈øimple ones, will you love ≈øimplicity, &c? Godly people may be in a ≈øtate of ignorance, but they love it not; therefore, 2 Pet. 3.5. the Scripture tells us of wicked men, that they are wilfully ignorant. So that if your ignorance have not this bad quality in it, to be a ≈øtubborne and wilfull ignorance, it may ≈øtand with your effectual calling.

Secondly, Provided that your ignorance be not a ≈øotti≈øh and bruti≈øh ignorance; that is, that you do not ≈øo lie clouded
in a ≈øtate of darkne≈ø≈øe, that you are uncapable to di≈øcerne the goodne≈ø≈øe of the Word, and uncapable to apprebend any thing that is taught you; that you are not like tho≈øe, Jer. 4.22. My people have no under≈øtanding, they are a ≈øotti≈øh people, wi≈øe to do evil, but to do good they have no under≈øtanding. Many men are ignorant men, yet not ≈øo ≈øotti≈øhly ignorant, as not to be capable of learning; if you will teach him, he is willing to be in≈øtructed; but ≈øome men are ≈øo ignorant, they are not capable of learning; you may as well teach a block as them. Hence it is the Prophet complains, E≈øa. 1.4. The Oxe knows his owner, and the A≈ø≈øe his Ma≈øters Crib, but I≈ørael knows not the Lord his God.

Thirdly, In ca≈øe your ignorance be not a fundamental ignorance, I mean ≈øuch an ignorance, as not to know tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øary and fundamental points in the Word, that mu≈øt be known, if ever you be ≈øaved; as about Je≈øus Chri≈øt and ≈øalvation, and ju≈øtification by his blood, and faith in his Name, &c. though you may be ignorant about circum≈øtantials, yet if it be not in fundamentals, your ignorance may be con≈øi≈øtent with effectual calling. But now

Thirdly, If a godly man be ≈øatisfied in the≈øe two points, and thinks happily, I may have the fir≈øt concomitant, to call upon God, and ≈øo evidence my effectual call; and then happily the ≈øecond may not be wanting in me, that I do not lie under the ≈øtate of a wilful ≈øotti≈øh & fundamental ignorance. But alas, ≈øaith he, I want a third concomitant that accompanies effectual calling, and that is; I finde in the Word, that they that are effectually called, they are brought into an Obediential frame of heart to all the wayes of God, that whatever God commands them to do, their hearts can readily obey, and this I finde, Rom. 1.5, 6. God hath called them by his grace unto the obedience of faith. Now alas, ≈øaith a poore ≈øoul. I finde a defect in this concomitant likewi≈øe, I cannot di≈øcerne that I am called to an obedience flowing from faith as its principle, I cannot finde this frame of heart to be in me, and therefore I doubt of my effectual calling This I ≈øhall labour to take off likewi≈øe.

Fir≈øt, When I ≈øay that obedience is a concomitant that will accompany one effectually called, I do not ≈øay nor intend it of obedience in the actings of it, but of an obediential frame of ≈øpirit in the purpo≈øes of it. Many men may be effectually called, In praeparatione animi. when they may not alwayes live in the acting of obedience to Chri≈øt but every man effectually called hath an obedient frame of heart; that is, he hath purpo≈øes & intentions and re≈øolutions to obey God, though he cannot act what he would do; he hath obedience in the habit, and obedience in his purpo≈øes and re≈øolutions always attending him.

Secondly, you finde in Scripture, that the ≈øtronge≈øt and able≈øt Chri≈øtians who have done mo≈øt for God, have ≈øometimes been very defective in the Actings of obedience, that they could not do what they would do for God. And therefore Paul complaines, Rom. 7. The good that we would do, we cannot do. Paul him≈øelf that was a pillar in Gods hou≈øe, yet he tells you, he could not go out in tho≈øe Actings of obedience, which in his heart he would do; & therfore if you would willingly do more then you do, God accepts of the litle you do.

Thirdly, Though you cannot put forth many Actings of obedience to God; where there is readine≈ø≈øe of minde and heart, God accepts the purpo≈øes of the minde for the Action it ≈øelf, 2 Cor. 8.12. Where there is a willing minde, it is accepted of God, as if the deed were done. And thus much be ≈øpoken to the ≈øecond ca≈øe of con≈øcience, why men effectually called do ≈øo much doubt of their own call.

Doubt. 3 Thirdly, Seeing Chri≈øtians mu≈øt put forth diligence in making their calling ≈øure; therefore now whereabouts mu≈øt this diligence of ours be conver≈øant? or into what Channel mu≈øt our diligence run, that ≈øo we might be ≈øure of our effectual calling? This is a very material que≈øtion; and in re≈øolving of it, I ≈øhall an≈øwer it in the≈øe two generals.
Fir≈øt, if you would get a≈ø≈øurance of your effectual calling, you mu≈øt put forth diligence to remove tho≈øe things that will hinder you in making ≈øure your calling. And
Secondly, u≈øe diligence to ≈øet upon the practice of tho≈øe duties that may further you in making this ≈øure, that you are effectually called.
Fir≈øt, You mu≈øt remove tho≈øe things which do much hinder you from being a≈ø≈øured, and tho≈øe hinderances that are to be removed, I ≈øhall comprize under ≈øix heads; As

Fir≈øt, you mu≈øt u≈øe diligence to remove Melancholy from your Thoughts; This is a natural hinderance of a≈ø≈øurance. Melancholy is a temper in man ari≈øing from a black blood running about the body, that doth naturally occa≈øion di≈øtru≈øt and fear in mens mindes; this temper being in the body, doth work much upon the di≈øpo≈øition of the ≈øoul. Now if your temper be Melancholy, and ≈øo di≈øpo≈øe you to di≈øtru≈øt and fear, this will be a great ≈øtop to your having of the joyes and comforts of the Lord in your hearts, in a≈ø≈øurance of his love. It is a note Perkins hath upon Nebuchadnezzar, when he are gra≈ø≈øe like a bea≈øt; he writing upon that place thinks, that Nebuchadnezzar was in a deep Melancholy, and that did ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe him, that he could not tell whether he was a man or a bea≈øt, though ≈øaith he, he did not eat gra≈ø≈øe, but his deep perplexity ≈øeazing upon him did make him think that he was from a man turned into a Bea≈øt. Beloved, Melancholy in a Chri≈øtian, it will make him think him≈øelf an Hypocrite, when he is a Saint; and therefore take heed of a Melancholy, lumpi≈øh and ≈øad temper; it is a very great hinderance to this grace of a≈ø≈øurance. This I lay down only as a Natural remedy.

Secondly, A minde filled with worldly cares, and running into incumbring imployments in the world, this is a great hinderance of a≈ø≈øurance. The cares of this life, Mat. 13.15. are compared to thornes. Now thornes they choake the ≈øeed, by drawing the juyce that is in the ≈øeed to them≈øelves, and ≈øo the corn doth not grow, where thornes ≈øpring. The cares of this life, they are like thornes in this, they are of an attractive power, to ≈øuck and draw the juyce of your ≈øpirits and comforts to them≈øelves, ≈øo that you cannot have the juyce of your ≈øpirits in gathering your evidences for heaven; the more incumbred you are in the world, the le≈ø≈øe clear you will be touching the evidence of your everla≈øting condition; The cares of this life, they pierce the ≈øoul through with many
≈øorrowes. Now when a man is pierced with many ≈øorrows, he is in a very unfit temper to be rai≈øed up in ≈øpiritual joy; the more you encumber your ≈øelves in the employments of this world, the le≈øs you wil be in the comforts of heaven. I remember it was the ≈øpeech of a Pope when he lay a dying, When I was a painful preaching Mini≈øter, then I had hopes of my ≈øalvation; when I came to be a Cardinal, I doubted of it: but when I came to be a Pope, I de≈øpaired of it; I was ≈øo entangled in the Affairs of this life: Beloved, ≈øo I may ≈øay to you, When you were but ordinary Chri≈øtians in the world, you were in a way to get a≈ø≈øurance of your ≈øalvation, but ≈øince you have been taken up with the affaires of the world, it doth ≈øo di≈øtract your minde, that you can be in no compo≈øed temper to have any ≈øetledne≈ø≈øe of heart about your everla≈øting e≈øtate. It is the ob≈øervation of Philo≈øophers, that the Sun is eclip≈øed by the interpo≈øition of the Moon, the Moon coming between the Sun and our ≈øight: Beloved, the Sun of your comforts comes to be eclip≈øed by the Moon, (which is made an Emblem of the world, Rev. 12.9.) Now if the Moon of the world comes between your comforts and you, it will mi≈øerably darken and eclip≈øe your comforts to you. Nothing in the world doth ≈øo impede your comfort in a≈ø≈øurance, as incumbring and carking cares about the things of this world.

Thirdly, Take heed you do not harbour the guilt of any one known ≈øin upon your con≈øcience. Keeping of ≈øin upon the con≈øcience, is a great impediment to your inward comforts. You will never be a≈ø≈øured while you do thus; and therefore if ever you would have a≈ø≈øurance, remove this. It is an ob≈øervation of Mr Hilder≈øham upon P≈øal. 51.12, 14. What doth David do, when he prayes for a≈ø≈øurance? ≈øaying, Re≈øtore to me the joyes of thy ≈øalvation, e≈øtabli≈øh me with thy free Spirit; Re≈øtore my comforts, and my evidences to me. And what cour≈øe doth he take? Read ver≈øe 14. Deliver me from blood-guiltine≈ø≈øe, O Lord. As much as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, All the while that ≈øin lay upon con≈øcience unrepented of, (as it did for nine monthes together) all that
while David lo≈øt the joyes of the Spirit, and lo≈øt the comforts of Heaven; And therefore when he comes to renew his comforts, and re≈øtore his a≈ø≈øurance, he doth with begging of God for a≈ø≈øurance, beg of God al≈øo to deliver him from blood-guiltine≈ø≈øe; as knowing, that if this ≈øin ≈øhould be upon con≈øcience unrepented of, and unpardoned, he ≈øhould never have the joyes of Gods Spirit re≈øtored. Beloved, you will never have a≈ø≈øurance of your effectual calling, till your con≈øciences are freed from having ≈øin upon them with approbation. But ≈øerves to beate down any opinion of our own righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as if we were therefore accepted of God; and to keep us from in≈øulting over the rejected Jewes; now that we are taken in, in their room.

One Scripture more (whch indeed is the main pillar they re≈øt upon) is, Rom. 11.34. Who hath known the minde of the Lord? or who hath been his Coun≈øellor? Here, ≈øay the Papi≈øts, the Scripture challengeth any man in the world to come forth, and ≈øay, that he knowes Gods mind; by Gods mind is meant Gods decree. And here Paul challengeth all, that no man knows the decree of God from eternity. Therefore, if no man knows the mind of God, then certainly none know their own election, for that is Gods mind, and Gods decree: this they hold an undeniable argument.
And here to ≈øatisfie you in this Scripture, I ≈øhall lay down three things.

Fir≈øt, When it is ≈øaid, No man knows the mind of God; nor no man is his Coun≈øellor: this doth hold true, that no man knows the mind or decree of the Lord, touching other mens election. The Apo≈øtle doth not ≈øpeak this, as if no man knew Gods minde about his own, but about other mens election, who are elected, and who are not; for that is the ≈øcope of the place. The Gentiles, they thought all the Jewes were damned men; and they cen≈øured and vaunted over them. Now, ≈øaith
Paul, None knows Gods mind concerning others, whether they ≈øhall be ≈øaved or damned, while they are in this world.

Secondly, no man knows the mind of the Lord in this ≈øen≈øe, that is, ≈øo as to give a rea≈øon of Gods decree; why God did decree this, and decree that; why God did chu≈øe Peter, and not elect Judas; no man knows the rea≈øon of Gods decree, and of his waies.

Thirdly, No man knows the mind of the Lord, that is, no man knows Gods decree, by looking upon it alone; but by bringing down Gods ≈øecret will to his revealed will; and ≈øo we may know his decree. I may make u≈øe of that place Rom. 10.8. Let no man ≈øay, I will a≈øcend up to heaven to fetch Chri≈øt thence; but what ≈øaith the word? the word is night thee, even in thy mouth. Tru≈øt to that. As if he ≈øhould ≈øay, Let no man think to know Gods decrees, by going into heaven, and there ≈øearching into Gods decrees, for that he cannot doe; but look upon the word, and there he ≈øhall finde whom God hath elected, and decreed to ≈øave, 1 Cor. 2.16. No man can know by looking barely upon the decree; but if we compare Gods decree with his word, and from the word look upon them that are elected, we may ea≈øily know whether we are elected or no. Which puts me upon the third head premi≈øed, How a man may be a≈ø≈øured in his own ≈øoule, that he is elected to life and ≈øalvation by God the Father.

div.head: SERMON XIII.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p: IN the pro≈øecution of this ≈øubject, you may remember, the la≈øt Doctrine I drew forth was this, That Chri≈øtians ≈øhould put forth a great deale of diligence to make this ≈øure to their ≈øoules, that they are eternally elected by God the Father. In the handling of which, I have ≈øhewn you, 1. what election is. 2. That the people of God may make ≈øure their own election, though done from all eternity.

I come now to ≈øhew you, how the people of God may be a≈ø≈øured in their own hearts that they are eternally elected. And here, to compa≈ø≈øe this knowledge or a≈ø≈øurance of our election, I doe not onely carry it ≈øo farre as the Papi≈øts doe, that ≈øay, you may have a per≈øwa≈øion, which they call, fides conjecturalis, a conjecturall faith, or hope you may be ≈øaved; but will not come up ≈øo farre as the words of my Text, to be ≈øure of it. Now ≈øhould a man u≈øe no more then the words of the Text, in that it is pre≈ø≈øed as a command, it is an argument it may be made ≈øure to a mans own ≈øelfe. For no man is bound to an impo≈ø≈øible thing; Nemo tenetur ad impo≈ø≈øibile. and in that it is a thing required, to be a≈ø≈øured of our election, the Scripture would never oblige our obedience to that which is impo≈ø≈øible in it ≈øelfe. I doe not drive ≈øo farre onely, but further. What ≈øhould an elect man doe to be certainly per≈øwaded that he is eternally elected by God to obtain life and ≈øalvation. I am now handling a doctrine to be trembled at, while you are attending to it. And in the re≈øolving of this query, you mu≈øt take this rule; that you cannot get a≈ø≈øumnce by a≈øcending into
Gods decree, but by de≈øcending into your own hearts, ≈øearching them by the word, whether tho≈øe ≈øaving effects, which God doth work in an elect per≈øon, be wrought in your ≈øoules or no ‚Ä¢ : and that is the way to come to a ≈øure and certain knowledge of your election. The knowledge of your election is not attainable by a≈øcending into Gods decree; for who hath made you his Coun≈øellors. Nor is it enjoyned you by way of Revelation. That is an un≈øure ground, and you may runne into Enthu≈øia≈øme, as well as per≈øwa≈øion about your election. It is not done by Revelation, neither again≈øt nor without the word. What ever te≈øtimony there is, if it come not from the word, you may ≈øu≈øpect it to be a delu≈øion. Now the ≈øafe≈øt way, (though I know much cried down) for you to goe by, in ≈øearching whether you are in the number of Gods elect, is to ≈øearch into your own hearts, whether tho≈øe things be wrought in you, which are wrought in tho≈øe whom God hath elected to life and ≈øalvation. And here I ≈øhall content my ≈øelfe with the naming of ≈øix ≈øaving effects.

Fir≈øt, every man that is elected, ≈øooner or latter, ≈øhall be effectually called, and ≈øavingly converted by the power of the word. This the Apo≈øtle laies down, 1 The≈ø. 1.4, 5. Knowing brethren, beloved, your election of God. How ≈øhould this be known? Ver≈ø. 5. For our word came not to you in word onely, but in power, and in the holy Gho≈øt: that is, our Go≈øpel did not come in word onely, to affect your eares, and re≈øt there; but our word came with power, being backt with the operation of the Spirit, for your conver≈øion. This work all men that are elected, ≈øooner or latter mu≈øt come under, to have the power of the word come with authority upon Con≈øcience, for his effectuall calling. So Rom. 8.30. Whom he prede≈øtinated, whom he appointed to life, them he called. And therefore, Beloved, who ever you are, if you live and die without having the power of the Word to pa≈ø≈øe upon your ≈øoule, for your effectuall Calling, you may lay your hearts under this Conclu≈øion, that you are not elected by God to obtaine life and ≈øalvation. For, Whom he hath prede≈øtinated, them he calls.

Secondly, a man that is elected by God to life, ≈øooner or
latter God will ≈øanctifie him by renewing and regenerating grace: And this is onely different from the former in degree; for calling is ≈øanctification begun. Now when God elects a man, he doth not onely begin the work of grace, but he carries it on in a cour≈øe of ≈øanctification. And of this you read 2 The≈ø. 2.12, 13. We are bold to give thanks to God alwaies for you, beloved of the Lord, becau≈øe God hath from the beginning cho≈øen you to ≈øalvation, through ≈øanctification of the Spirit, and beliefe of the truth. If God hath from the beginning cho≈øen a man to ≈øalvation, the Lord doth it through ≈øanctification; not for ≈øanctification, as the Papi≈øts ≈øay, or for faith for≈øeen, but it is through it, as a means whereby we are brought to ≈øalvation; ≈øanctification ≈øhall runne through your lives, as water through a channel. So, 1 Pet. 1.2. They that are elected according to the foreknowledge of God the Father, by Chri≈øt, through ≈øanctification. So 2 Tim. 2.21. And therefore beloved, if men live and die, and have not the power of ≈øanctifying grace upon their hearts and con≈øciences, and working in their lives, doubtle≈ø≈øe tho≈øe men are not elected; becau≈øe this you ≈øee clearly, that at one time or other God will work this in ≈øuch men. Jude 4.

Thirdly, men elected by God to life and ≈øalvation ≈øhall ≈øooner or latter be brought into a ≈øtate of believing, Acts 13.48. As many as were ordained to eternall life believed. No man that is ordained to eternall life, but ≈øhall be brought to a believing e≈øtate. And therefore men living and dying in a ≈øtate of unbeliefe, are not elected. Hence you read, Tit. 1.1. it is called, the faith of Gods elect; implying, that all that are elected, before they die ≈øhall have faith; and none ≈øhall have faith, but onely they; and therefore in a peculiar manner called the faith of Gods elect, appropriated onely to them.

Fourthly, That man that is elected, ≈øooner, or latter before he dies, God will work in his heart a ≈øpeciall delight in, and an intire love to the word preached. This you have expre≈ø≈øed, John 8.47. He that is of God, heareth Gods word; therefore ye are not of God, becau≈øe you heare not his words. To be of God, that is, to belong to God by election. Now, he that is of God,
God will in time make him heare his Word with delight and love; but he that takes no delight therein, is not elected of God. 1 John 4.5, 6.

Fifthly, The Lord will ≈øooner or latter work in the heart of an elect man, love to the people of God, and compa≈ø≈øion to tho≈øe who are not the elect and cho≈øen ones of God, Col. 3.12. Put on as the elect of God, bowels of mercy and loving kindne≈øs. The Apo≈øtle there by the manner of phra≈øe doth ≈øeem to intimate thus much, Put on as the elect of God, &c. As if it were a thing ordained to, and in≈øeparable from an elect man, after his effectuall calling, that he ≈øhould have bowels of mercy towards tho≈øe that are not called, and that he ≈øhould have loving kindne≈ø≈øe towards tho≈øe that are called. For a man that is once elected, and hath the execution of that decree in effectuall calling, it is proper to him to have bowels of mercy.

Sixtly, God will ≈øooner or latter work an elect man into a new cour≈øe of living, and of obedience, from what he had in times pa≈øt. 1 Pet. 1.2. You are elected according to the foreknowledge of God through ≈øanctification to obedience; that though you were di≈øobedient before, ≈øerving divers lu≈øts, yet God, if he hath cho≈øen you, will bring you into a cour≈øe of obedience, Rom. 8.29. He hath prede≈øtinated us. What to doe? that we might be conformable to the image of his Sonne.
