God intends, that that per≈øon whom he choo≈øeth to life, ≈øhould be conformable to Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and that he ≈øhall live another manner of life then before; that though he hath formerly been ≈øubject to ≈øinne and Satan, yet then he ≈øhall walk in waies of obedience to Je≈øus Chri≈øt.
Thus having briefly fini≈øht the≈øe heads, I have onely foure or five cautions to lay down, to bound what hath been ≈øaid within the limits of truth. As,

Fir≈øt, Take notice, that the≈øe ≈øix effects doe not extend to children who die while they are children, but to men and women that are grown to yeers. A child that cannot act rea≈øon, as he is a child, cannot have any of the≈øe particulars wrought in him, at lea≈øt in that way and manner men of yeeres have. A child, as it is an infant, hath not conver≈øion in that way a
man hath, though it hath ≈øomewhat equivalent to it; as ≈øomewhat like ≈øanctification, and ≈øomewhat like that faith men of yeeres have; but what that is, and how wrought, man cannot determine. In pre≈ø≈øing of this therefore, I ≈øay, it doth not extend to children who die in their infancy, but onely to men come to yeeres of di≈øcretion, if they live and die without the having of the≈øe ≈øix effects, they may conclude, they cannot be elected.

Secondly, that the want of the≈øe ≈øix particulars for a time, is no Argument of a mans non-election: for before conver≈øion (which is Gods fir≈øt dealing with a ≈øinner) an elect man may be as vile, and as bad as any wicked man alive. As the Apo≈øtle Paul tels us, Titus 3.3. In times pa≈øt we were al≈øo di≈øobedient, and ≈øerved divers lu≈øts, and lived in plea≈øure and exce≈ø≈øe, &c. So 1 Tim. 1.12. So that the want of this for a time, is no argument of a mans non-election, for then it would follow, a man unconverted is no elect man, which would cro≈ø≈øe the whole tenour of Scripture: But a man living and dying without the≈øe, doth not belong to the election of grace.

Thirdly, I doe not pre≈ø≈øe the having of the≈øe effects actually, if you have them habitually. My meaning is this: A man may be elected, and yet may not act any thing an≈øwerable to effectuall calling, nor act with any delight and love to the word, nor act any thing in a way of ≈øanctification; yet, if you have the≈øe habitually, in the habit of them, the≈øe may be te≈øtimonies or evidences of election.

Fourthly, I doe not pre≈ø≈øe the having of the≈øe effects ≈øen≈øibly to be an evidence of election, if ≈øo be you have them really. There are many men have the≈øe really, when they have them not in their own apprehen≈øion.

Fifthly, I doe not pre≈ø≈øe the having of the≈øe effects gradually, ≈øo you have them ≈øincerely. My meaning is this, that a man may be elected; yea, and he may not onely be cho≈øen in Gods eternall decree, but the execution of that decree may be pa≈ø≈øed upon him, that he may be effectually called, and yet he may not have all the≈øe ≈øix effects in a great mea≈øure, in
the highe≈øt degree, yet he may have them ≈øincerely, and ≈øo be a pledge to his own heart of his eternall election.

And thus having fini≈øhed this third Query, I come now to enter upon another, depending upon the former; which indeed is a very dreadfull ≈øubject, and a point to be trembled at, while it is handling, and that is this: what probable gue≈ø≈øe may be given of a man, that he is not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election? This is a very high point, and mu≈øt be handled with a great deale of ≈øeriou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øadne≈ø≈øe; it being a point concerning the ≈øalvation or damnation of all the men upon earth. And therfore I would intreat you to look about you. Gods decrees they are in Heaven, and it is onely a reall work of grace upon your hearts on earth, that can give you evidence that tho≈øe decrees are for good to you. As good wrought is an evidence of Gods purpo≈øe to ≈øave you; ≈øo the contrary work may be an evidence of Gods purpo≈øe never to ≈øave you, but of leaving you without the compa≈ø≈øe of his eternall election. There can be nothing laid down ab≈øolutely and certainly, yet there may be many probable gue≈ø≈øes given of the men that are not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election: Of which I ≈øhall name but ≈øix or ≈øeven ≈øorts. And I wi≈øh to God, that none of you that are before the Lord this day, have your names written in this black book, le≈øt you have ju≈øt cau≈øe to feare your names are not written in the booke of life.

Fir≈øt, That man that fals back from a cour≈øe of profe≈ø≈øion to a cour≈øe of prophanene≈ø≈øe, without timely returning; the Scripture gives a ≈øhrewd gue≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch a man, that he is not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods purpo≈øe to ≈øave. I doe not ≈øay, every back≈øliding, and every decaying affection, but a totall and finall relap≈øe; when a man falls, and ri≈øeth not againe; when a man runs from God, and returns not again; the Scripture gives a gue≈ø≈øe at him, that he is not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election. Heb. 10.38, 39. If any man draw back, my ≈øoule ≈øhall have no plea≈øure in him. Interpreters ob≈øerve, that in the≈øe words there is a figure, wherein there is le≈ø≈øe expre≈ø≈øed, then is intended, My ≈øoule ≈øhall have no plea≈øure in him.
It is as much as if God ≈øhould have ≈øaid, My ≈øoule ≈øhall hate, or I will exceedingly hate him. But we are not of them that draw back to perdition; but of them that believe, to the ≈øaving of their ≈øoules: which words clearly import, that men that draw back without returning, they draw back to perdition, to damnation; but we are not of them, ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle. And here then, beloved, doth this word fall upon any man before God this day? Ha≈øt thou left a cour≈øe of ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe, and fallen into a cour≈øe of prophanene≈ø≈øe and loo≈øene≈ø≈øe? Ha≈øt thou fallen from thy God, and never thinke≈øt of a returning? I ≈øhall not cen≈øure thee now, but if thou live≈øt and die≈øt in this e≈øtate, it is an undoubted argument, thou art not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods decree to ≈øave.

Secondly, Men that doe make the mercies and goodne≈ø≈øe of God as arguments to embolden them the more in ≈øinne, ≈øuch men are not likely to be the per≈øons whom God hath elected to life and glory. In the Epi≈øtle of Jude, v. 4. It is ≈øpoken there of men, that turned the grace of God into wantonne≈ø≈øe. And what ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle of them, they are men that are ordained of old to condemnation. The Scripture there makes it the badge of a man ordained of old to condemnation, when he ≈øhal per≈øi≈øt in this ≈øinfull temper, to turn Gods grace into la≈øciviou≈øne≈ø≈øe; that is, to take arguments from the grace, and mercy and goodne≈ø≈øe of God, to walk in waies of ≈øinne. And therefore look to it, and with your hearts bewaile it, all you that are apt to abu≈øe doctrines of grace; and becau≈øe God is good, you will be evil; becau≈øe God is mercifull, therefore you will be ≈øinful; if you die in this temper, the Scripture declares, that you are the men ordained of old to condemnation.

Thirdly, a man that doth walk in a cour≈øe of ≈øinne, wilfully, with malice, and knowingly again≈øt con≈øcience, and ob≈øtinately without reluctancy; and per≈øi≈øt in this, and live and die thus, that man is not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election. There is a phra≈øe, P≈øal. 59.5. Be not mercifull, O Lord, unto wicked tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors. It is in ≈øome tran≈ølations, Be not mercifull to them that ≈øinne of wicked malice, or of malicious wickedne≈ø≈øe. Now there is this rule which Divines give; that
tho≈øe prayers which were made by David, they are rather Prophecies of what ≈øhould be, then meere prayers that this might be. As David prayed again≈øt the Jewes, P≈øal. 69.22. that their table might be a ≈ønare to them, and that they ≈øhould alway bow down under their burden: which was a prophecie, and they did ≈øo. And ≈øo he prayes here, that God would not be mercifull to men that ≈øinne of wicked malice; which is as much as a prophecie, that God will not be mercifull to men that ≈øinne of malicious wickedne≈ø≈øe. And therefore, beloved, all you that ≈øo live, and re≈øolve you will die, and haply doe die; who ≈øinne ob≈øtinately, that, let God command what he can, you will do what you plea≈øe; let the Mini≈øter ≈øay what he will, you will doe as you li≈øt; that ≈øinne again≈øt knowledge, and again≈øt con≈øcience, and without any reluctancy, re≈øolve to live and die in a cour≈øe of ≈øinne: the Lord be mercifull to ≈øuch per≈øons; for certainly there mu≈øt be no Bible, if ≈øuch men fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election.

Fourthly, That man that by living under the powerfull Mini≈øtry of the Word, is more hard in heart, and wor≈øe in life; if a man grows thus, it is an argument, he is not within the purpo≈øe of Gods election. Matth. 13.14, 15. By hearing, you ≈øhall heare, but not under≈øtand; by ≈øeeing, you ≈øhall ≈øee, but not perceive; this peoples heart is waxed gro≈ø≈øe, their eares dull in hearing, their eyes ≈øhut, le≈øt at any time they ≈øhould ≈øee with their eyes, heare with their eares, under≈øtand with their hearts, and be converted, and I ≈øhould ≈øave them. Here is the judgement God laies upon ≈øuch ≈øinners, that they ≈øhall have eyes, and not ≈øee, they ≈øhall be ignorant, their hearts ≈øhall waxe gro≈ø≈øe, they ≈øhall be uncapable of taking any impre≈ø≈øion of the word upon them. And what's the end of all this? le≈øt they ≈øhould be converted, and I ≈øhould ≈øave them; implying, that if God lets you that live under the Mini≈øtry, to have dark eyes, and hard hearts, it is an argument God hath no intent to ≈øave you, and therefore his purpo≈øe is to condemne you. So John 12.40. He hath blinded their eyes, and hardned their hearts, le≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øee with their eyes, and under≈øtand with their hearts and be converted. Here it is laid down as an act of
Gods, that God did harden their hearts, and God did blind their eyes, le≈øt they ≈øhould be converted; Implying, that if men doe live and die, in this temper, that they have lived yeere after yeere under a powerfull Mini≈øtry, and yet they grow more blind in judgement, and more profane in life, and more hard in heart, after 20, 30, 40 yeeres hearing, then they were before; that the word doth but draw out their wickedne≈ø≈øe, and makes them more prophane, and more to oppo≈øe godline≈ø≈øe; the Lord have mercy upon ≈øuch ≈øoules, for certainly if God leave you thus, it is an argument he never intends to ≈øave you; for the Lord doth thus with ≈øuch, that they might not be ≈øaved. There is a pa≈ø≈øage Rom. 11.7. I≈ørael hath not obtained that which he ≈øeeks for, but the election hath obtained, and the re≈øt were hardned. By election is meant the elected, (the Ab≈øtract put for the Concrete.) As often in Scripture, Circumci≈øion put for Circumci≈øed; and ≈øo here, Election put for elected, The elected have obtained it: what did they obtaine? they obtained ≈øalvation and glory; but the re≈øt, that were not elected, they were hardned. The Lord there makes it the badge of them that are not elected, that they are a blinded people, and a hardned people. Intimating, that men that are not elected, they ≈øhall live under the word, yet ≈øhall be blind in mind, ≈øhall be hard in heart, ≈øhall be wicked in life, and the Mini≈øtry of the word ≈øhall never reforme them. And if any of you be ≈øuch, O that the Lord would make you tremble this day, tremble le≈øt you are not in Gods thoughts, to doe you any good another day.

Fifthly, when God doth give up men to ≈øtrong delu≈øions, not onely to believe lies them≈øelves, but to teach lies to ≈øeduce others, when the Lord leaves men to live and die in that e≈øtate, the Scripture makes it an argument of them that are not cho≈øen by God to life and glory. You ≈øhall read therefore in that great delu≈øion of Antichri≈øt, 2 The≈ø. 2.10, 11, 12. God gave them up to ≈øtrong delu≈øions, to believe lies, that all might be damned, that believe not the truth? It is made a brand of damnation, when God ≈øhall give them over to believe lies. Though a godly man may die in a corrupt opinion, for every
errour is not a badge of damnation; but errours that are fundamentall, that ≈øtrike at the foundation of Religion, wherein men runne ≈øo far, as never to repent of their errour; that, the Scripture makes the badge of a man, who≈øe ≈øoule is in a world of danger. Read that Text, 2 Pet. 2.1, 2, 3. There were fal≈øe Prophets among the people, like as there ≈øhall be fal≈øe Teachers among you. And who are they? ver≈ø. 2. They ≈øhall deny the Lord that bought them, they ≈øhall bring in damnable here≈øies. (Every errour is not a here≈øie,) but the≈øe men ≈øhall bring in damnable here≈øies, and many ≈øhall follow their pernicious waies. Now what is their cen≈øure? who≈øe judgement now of a long time lingers not, and their damnation ≈ølumbers not. Their damnation was not a≈øleep, but for a long time damnation did attend them, and they were in danger of it. So that, beloved, it is great danger for men to be patrons of errour, e≈øpecially when they are gro≈ø≈øe and palpable; and when in Scripture language they may be called damnable here≈øies. It is an argument, if men live and die thus, that they are not within the purpo≈øe of Gods Coun≈øell to doe them good.

Sixthly, Men that live and die in a continuall ≈øpurning and oppo≈øition again≈øt the Go≈øpell, and word of God powerfully preached, it is a dreadfull ≈øigne they are not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election. 1 John 4, 5, 6. You are not of God, for you heare not his words. So John. 12. He that heareth the word, is of God, but you heare not his word, therefore you are not of God. Therefore you belong not to him. But more pregnant to this purpo≈øe, is that place, Acts 13.46, 47, 48. It was nece≈ø≈øary the word of the Lord ≈øhould fir≈øt have been ≈øpoken to you, but ≈øeeing you put it from you, and judge your ≈øelves unworthy of everla≈øting life, lo, we turn to the Gentiles. Now compare this with Ver≈ø. 48. And when the Gentiles heard this, they were glad, and glorified the word of the Lord, and as many as were ordained to eternall life, believed. The oppo≈øition lies thus: As many as God purpo≈øed to ≈øave, they glorified God for his word, and they rejoyced, and were glad in his word: but tho≈øe that were not decreed to ≈øalvation, they put off from them the word of the Lord, they ≈øpurned at it, and oppo≈øed it, and
could not indure the word of the Lord. Therefore the Text ≈øaith, The Jewes ≈øtirred up the devout and honourable women, and they rai≈øed up per≈øecution again≈øt Paul and Barnabas, and expelled them out of their coa≈øt. It was ≈øaid to Amaziah, 2 Chro. 25.16. By this I know, that the Lord hath purpo≈øed to de≈øtroy thee, becau≈øe thou ha≈øt not hearkned to my coun≈øell. Thus you ≈øee, the Scripture makes it the badge of a man, that doth not fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, to bring him to life and glory, to live and die in oppo≈øition to the word of God.

Sevently, and this we may ≈øpeake more confidently and po≈øitively, that that man is not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, who ≈øinnes the ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, Matth. 12.32. He ≈øhall neither be forgiven in this life, nor in the life to come. This is an unpardonable ≈øinne, 1 John 5.16. Now I know there are many men, who confine this ≈øinne onely to the Phari≈øees, as if they onely were guilty of it. There are others, that ≈øay this ≈øinne is ≈øeldome committed; and ≈øo many Divines ≈øpeak favourably of it: but, Beloved, I am per≈øwaded, this ≈øinne is oftner committed, then mo≈øt men in the world dream of; and many men are plunged into this ≈øinne, that think well of their own ≈øoules. The ≈øinne again≈øt the holy Gho≈øt, is onely this.

It is a wilfull and deliberate act in a profe≈ø≈øor of Religion, whereby he doth not onely fall from his profe≈ø≈øion; but he runnes into a cour≈øe of ≈øinne knowingly, again≈øt con≈øcience; ob≈øtinately, again≈øt coun≈øell; and maliciou≈øly, again≈øt Je≈øus Chri≈øt. This is briefly a de≈øcription of this ≈øinne. Now I am per≈øwaded there are many in the world that have profe≈ø≈øed Religion, that are, if not in this ≈øinne, yet at the very next doore to it. And if a man be gone thus farre, this is called in Scripture, a ≈øinne unto death; a ≈øinne, which if a man fall into, he may be ≈øure he ≈øhall be damned. And thus I have in briefe given you an account of the≈øe ≈øeven particulars, whereby every man may give a gue≈ø≈øe in his own thoughts, whether he be within the purpo≈øe of Gods election to ≈øalvation, or no.
I have now, from this ≈øad Doctrine, onely a few comfortable po≈øitions to lay down, and ≈øo conclude. As,

1. That though the≈øe particulars may give you a gue≈ø≈øe of tho≈øe that are not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, yet no man is bound to make this ≈øure to him≈øelfe, that he is not elected. You are bound to make your election ≈øure, but you are not bound to make your reprobation ≈øure. For the≈øe heads I have given out, not to make any godly man que≈øtion his election, but to ≈øtartle wicked men, who live quite contrary, and oppo≈øite to the elect of God.

2. That a man may come very nigh to the wor≈øt of the≈øe ≈øins, and yet may be an elect man. We were (≈øaith Paul) ≈øometimes di≈øobedient, deceived, and ≈øerved divers lu≈øts. Titus 3.3. And Ephe≈ø. 2.2. In times pa≈øt you walked according to the cour≈øe of the world, according to the power of the Prince of the aire, who worketh mightily in the children of di≈øobedience. In times pa≈øt you were children of wrath, as well as others. In times pa≈øt before calling, you may come very neere to the≈øe evils, yet be within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, provided you doe not live and die in tho≈øe evils. For if ≈øo, there is no hope of mercy.

3. That for men to que≈øtion their election, meerly becau≈øe they doe not finde the ≈øaving effects of election in their hearts and lives, is rather an argument of their being, then of their not being elected. Becau≈øe men not elected, they never look after their election, to make it ≈øure, they will tru≈øt all upon the mercy of God, and grace of God, and never look after holine≈ø≈øe; ≈øin never troubles them, profanene≈ø≈øe never grieves them, want of holine≈ø≈øe perplexes not them. The que≈øtioning therefore of your election ari≈øing from the evils of your conver≈øation, is rather a ≈øigne that God hath cho≈øen you to life and glory.

4. Election it runnes often times to tho≈øe, that are the wor≈øt ≈øort of men in the world. Election runnes to them that have been wor≈øt in their lives, before they were called. And thereby God magnifies the riches of his grace. Election pa≈ø≈øeth by civill hone≈øt men, and ingenious tempered men, and
commonly runs to men, that have been ≈øcandalous, loo≈øe, Athei≈øticall, profane livers, before they were called. Matth. 21.31. Whores and Harlots ≈øhall come to Heaven before you. Mana≈ø≈øeh, that was a cruell murderer, and Idolater, yet election ran to him. Mary Magdalen, a common ≈øtrumpet, out of whom Chri≈øt ca≈øt ≈øeven Divels, yet election ran to her. Rahab, a Harlot; Paul, a per≈øecuter, a bla≈øphemer, a man injurious to the Saints; yet Acts 9.15. He was a cho≈øen ve≈ø≈øell unto God, and obtained mercy. God, to magnifie the riches of his free grace, lets election run to the wor≈øt of men that are in the world. And this ≈øhould be great comfort to you; though you have been drunkards, and though you have been Sabbath breakers and adulterers, and though you have been profane, yet if you can but now clo≈øe in with Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and looke after heaven, if you can but now mourn over your condition, and repent of your former failings, and come in to Je≈øus Chri≈øt; Election hath runne unto men as bad as you, and though you may be now men profane in your lives, yet you may be objects of Gods election.

div.head: SERMON XIV.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p: THe la≈øt Doctrine I drew from the≈øe words, was this, That Chri≈øtians ≈øhould put forth a great deale of diligence to make this ≈øure to their ≈øoules, that they are eternally elected by God to life and glory. In the pro≈øecution of which, I have gone over ≈øome queries. There are four difficulties or queries I am further to in≈øi≈øt upon in treating of this point. As namely,
Fir≈øt, whether this election be univer≈øall, or no?
Secondly, whether a man that is once elected by God to ≈øalvation, may come to be damned, yea, or no?
Thirdly, whether God, in electing a man to life and glory, doth it out of any fore≈øight of faith, or any other grace he ≈øees in man?

And fourthly, whether this doctrine of election, that God in his own coun≈øell hath determined, who ≈øhall be damned, and who ≈øaved, doth not take men off from any endeavours after their own ≈øalvation, to make them de≈øperate, and neglect the u≈øe of means; that they ≈øhall ≈øay, if I ≈øhall be damned, I ≈øhall be damned; and if ≈øaved, I ≈øhall be ≈øaved, let me live as I li≈øt? whether this doctrine will favour this de≈øperate conclu≈øion, yea, or no?

Fir≈øt, whether election be univer≈øall, or no? This is that the Arminians and Papi≈øts doe mightily drive at. And here they lay down this conclu≈øion, which they make unque≈øtionable: That there is ≈øuch a thing as a certain univer≈øall election of God, without limitation or re≈øtraint of per≈øons, whereby
God did determine to ≈øave all mankind by Chri≈øt, who were fallen in Adam. This opinion was fir≈øt drawn from Origen, who held that all creatures ≈øhould be ≈øaved; and the Papi≈øts and Arminians mincing the matter, to make it a little more plau≈øible, then he did, they ≈øay, that God in his purpo≈øe did intend to ≈øave all mankind by Je≈øus Chri≈øt; but man falling away, and walking contrary to their principles, the defect lies in them, that they are not ≈øaved: and this Divines call univer≈øall redemption.
Now again≈øt this, I ≈øhall lay down ≈øeverall Scriptures, and then take off the objections that ≈øeems to ≈øtrengthen this opinion.

Fir≈øt, for Scriptures. In the Epi≈øtle of Jude, ver≈ø. 3. you read of ≈øome that were ordained of old to condemnation. Therefore ≈øure all could not be ≈øaved. 1 The≈ø. 5.9. Some men are appointed to wrath, but we to obtain ≈øalvation through Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Therefore all men could not be within the purpo≈øe of Gods fir≈øt intention to ≈øave. Matth. 22.14. Many are called, but few are cho≈øen. So Rom. 11.7. The Jewes did not obtaine what they ≈øought for, but the elect obtained it, and the re≈øt were hardned. 2 Tim. 2.20. There are ve≈ø≈øels of honour, and ve≈ø≈øels of di≈øhonour. The Scripture makes it a di≈øcriminating act in God, that ≈øome he cho≈øe to life; and others from eternity in his councell he cho≈øe to wrath and condemnation. And the≈øe Scriptures will fully overthrow this opinion. And indeed the very word chu≈øing confutes it, which intimates a taking of ≈øome, with an overlooking of others.
But now let us view a little the Arguments or Scriptures they abu≈øe, to ≈øtrengthen this un≈øound opinion of theirs.

One is, 1 Cor. 15.22. As in Adant all died, even ≈øo in Chri≈øt ≈øhall all be made alive. Now, ≈øay they, Every man did die in Adam; every mothers child by Adams fall became ≈øubject to death: even ≈øo, in Chri≈øt ≈øhall every man be made alive; the Lord did intend that every man ≈øhould have benefit by Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Now to take off this; I ≈øhall an≈øwer it in ≈øhewing you the true intent and ≈øcope of this Scripture. This univer≈øall phra≈øe
of making alive, hath not reference to the ≈øaving of the ≈øoule, but to the re≈øurrection of the body: And ≈øo the ≈øence is this. That as in Adam, by vertue of his ≈øinne, every man came to die a naturall death; So in Chri≈øt ≈øhall all be made alive; that is, ≈øo by Chri≈øts power ≈øhall every man ri≈øe from the dead. And if you aske how I make that appeare to be the intendment of the Text. I an≈øwer, the words them≈øelves will make it plaine. Ver≈ø. 11. It is ≈øaid, By man came death, by man al≈øo came the re≈øurrection from the dead: that is, as by that man Adam came death, ≈øo by that man Chri≈øt ≈øhall come the re≈øurrection from the dead: for as in Adam all died, &c. ≈øo that here you ≈øee, this is brought in as a proofe of the 21. ver≈øe: Intimating, that this being made alive, hath no reference to the life of the ≈øoule, but onely to the Re≈øurrection of the body; that as Adam by his ≈øinne brought death to all men, ≈øo Chri≈øt by his power ≈øhall rai≈øe all men from the dead; every man in his own order. However, ≈øhould this be granted, that this making alive ≈øhould have reference to the life of the ≈øoul; it would beare no more but this, that all that are damned, are damned as in Adams loynes; and all that are ≈øaved, ≈øhall be ≈øaved as in the loynes of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. And ≈øo make nothing at all to prove this which they call univer≈øall election.

Another Scripture (undeniable they think) is, Rom. 11.32. where it is ≈øaid, God hath concluded all men under unbeliefe, that he might have mercy upon all. Now ≈øay they, If God did doe an act to make men ≈øee their unbeliefe, and did intend by this action to have mercy upon all, then God in his coun≈øell intended to ≈øave all.

Now to this, that he might have mercy upon all; I an≈øwer: This phra≈øe (all) is not to be taken in an unlimited ≈øence, as if he would have mercy upon all mankind; but it is to be taken in a re≈øtrained ≈øence, that God ≈øhut up all men in unbeliefe; that is, God made all believers ≈øee their own mi≈øery; that he might have mercy on all them that believe. And if you ask how I prove this to be the meaning of the Text, I an≈øwer: The Scripture makes it cleare, Gal. 3.22. The Scripture hath concluded all men under ≈øinne. (The very words forequoted.)
But what's the limitation? Shall all men be ≈øaved? No. For mark the next words. The Scripture hath concluded all men under ≈øinne, that the promi≈øe by the faith of Je≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhould be given to them that believe. Now, though Paul doth not ≈øay thus to the Romans, yet the words being the ≈øame, the Re≈øtriction holds good in both places. So that it is clear, That he might ≈øave all, or have mercy upon all. It is not meant all univer≈øally; but all, with this limitation of Paul here; all them that believe. Again,

Another objection, or Scripture, they abu≈øe is, 1 Tim. 2.4. Who will have all men to be ≈øaved, and to come to the knowledge of the truth. This Text Origen doth gro≈øly abu≈øe; holding hence, that it is the intendment and will of God, that all men ≈øhould be ≈øaved. Now, to take off this objection; We mu≈øt fir≈øt di≈øtingui≈øh here of Gods will, and then of this phra≈øe, All. Who will have all men to be ≈øaved.
Fir≈øt, of Gods will; Voluntas ben ‚Ä¢ placiti & voluntas ≈øigni. and the Schoolmen give this di≈øtinction about it. That there is a will of Gods good plea≈øure; and there is Gods ≈øignifying will.

Now the will of Gods good plea≈øure is, that reall purpo≈øe in God to ≈øave a man. And there is no man that in this ≈øence God wils to be ≈øaved, but he mu≈øt be ≈øaved; but in this ≈øence God wils not all men to be ≈øaved.

But ≈øecondly, there is Gods ≈øignificative will, that is, whereby in Scripture God tenders ≈øalvation to every man that will lay hold upon Je≈øus Chri≈øt: and ≈øo Gods ≈øignifying will excludes no man from ≈øalvation; but the Mini≈øters, if they preach to ten thou≈øand people, they mu≈øt tender Chri≈øt univer≈øally to them all, becau≈øe they know not which of them are elect, and which reprobate; which of them ≈øhall be ≈øaved, and which damned. This is Gods ≈øignifying will, and though God by this will tell you what Mini≈øters mu≈øt doe, to tender Chri≈øt and ≈øalvation to all; yet this doth no way follow, that the determinate will of Gods good plea≈øure is involved under this, as if all men ≈øhould be ≈øaved. Perkins in his writings hath this di≈øtinction of it. That there is Gods ab≈øolute will, and ≈øo he wils not all men to be ≈øaved: and Gods conditionate
will, that in ca≈øe every man did believe, they ≈øhould be ≈øaved; for God envies no mans ≈øalvation; there is grace enough in God, and willingne≈ø≈øe enough in God, to ≈øave every man in the world.

But ≈øecondly, there may be a more di≈øtinct an≈øwer given to this place. God will have all men to be ≈øaved. All, is taken ≈øometimes in a di≈øtributive ≈øence, and ≈øometimes in a collective ≈øence. In a di≈øtributive ≈øence, for every man under heaven; and ≈øo God wils not all men to be ≈øaved. But ≈øecondly, in a collective ≈øence; for all ≈øorts and degrees of men, and ≈øo God intends to ≈øave all; that is, ≈øome of all ≈øorts, and of all degrees of men in the world. And this appeares if you mark the context. He will have all men to be ≈øaved, that is, ≈øome of all ≈øorts. Some Kings, and ≈øome great men, ≈øome rich, and ≈øome poore, ≈øome Princes, and ≈øome beggars. And therefore the Apo≈øtle bids them pray for all men. Pray, ≈øaith he, for Kings, and for them in authority: for God will have all men to be ≈øaved. As much as if he ≈øhould ≈øay, Pray for Kings, becau≈øe God of his grace may ≈øave Kings, as well as poorer men, that have le≈ø≈øe incumbrances, and le≈ø≈øe imployments in the world, and le≈ø≈øe withdrawings in their own ≈øoule, then they have. God will ≈øave all: ≈øalvation ≈øhall come to all ≈øorts of men, and therefore you may lawfully pray for them. And ≈øo Calvin judiciou≈øly expounds this place; that God will have all ≈øorts of men to obtaine ≈øalvation by Je≈øus Chri≈øt: but is not to be extended univer≈øally, as if every individuall man and woman ≈øhould be ≈øaved. 3. The≈øe words are to be taken with tho≈øe that follow after, God will have all men to be ≈øaved, and to come to the knowledge of the truth. Now that God will be willing to ≈øave tho≈øe that come to the knowledge of the truth, is unque≈øtionable; all that repent, Acts 17.30. all oppo≈øition to the time of the old Te≈øtament, Rom. 16.25.

∆≤≈øe. Now, is this true, that election is not univer≈øall; but that ≈øome men are elected, and others reprobated? Then, to wrap up this query in a ≈øhort u≈øe; this ≈øhould teach you all, who are in the land of the living, not to deceive your ≈øelves; lull
not your ≈øelves a≈øleep in ≈øecurity, for it may be, you may be in Gods coun≈øell to ≈øave, it may be not. Peradventure you may be in Gods thoughts for ≈øalvation, peradventure you may be in his coun≈øell for damnation; and this ≈øhould put you upon the work my text calls upon you for, to endeavour to make your calling and election ≈øu ‚Ä¢ e.

2. A ≈øecond Query is this, Whether may one that is an elect man, fall away from his election, and come to be a damned man, or no? This the Prote≈øtant Divines again≈øt the Arminians and Papi≈øts have had large controver≈øies about, but I will not handle it in a controver≈øall way, onely, as it be≈øt becomes a Pulpit, ≈øhew you tho≈øe po≈øitive Scriptures and rea≈øons that may cleare the truth, and then an≈øwer the ≈øtronge≈øt objections they produce to the contrary.

Q. Whether may a man that is elected fall away, and afterward peri≈øh? To this I an≈øwer. No. A man that is once elected by God can never peri≈øh. And this I ≈øhall give Scripture, and rea≈øon to plead for it. Matth. 24.24. Chri≈øt tels us of errour, that it came in ≈øo ea≈øily, that if it were po≈ø≈øible, it would deceive the elect. Intimating, that it is impo≈ø≈øible ≈øo to ≈øeduce the elect, as to make them finally fall away. So, John 6.37. All that the Father hath given me, ≈øhall come unto me: that is, all that God the Father hath decreed to ≈øave by Chri≈øt, ≈øhall come unto Chri≈øt. Ver≈ø. 39. This is the Fathers will, that hath ≈øent me, that of all that he hath given me, I ≈øhould lo≈øe none. This is the Fathers will, and Commi≈ø≈øion to Chri≈øt, that of all tho≈øe that by his decree he had given to Chri≈øt to ≈øave by redemption, he ≈øhould lo≈øe none. And ≈øaith Chri≈øt, I have lo≈øt nothing. So John 10.28, 29. I give unto my ≈øheep eternall life, and they ≈øhall never peri≈øh, neither ≈øhall any man take them out of my hands; my Father that gave them me, is greater then all, and no man ≈øhall pluck them out of my Fathers hands. By his Fathers hands, he means his decree; God by his decree intended to ≈øave ≈øo many, and Chri≈øt to vindicate his Father, tels us, that ≈øo many as God the Father had decreed to ≈øalvation, neither man nor divell ≈øhould prevaile to pluck them out of his Fathers hand. So Rom. 11.1. God hath
not ca≈øt away his people whom he ≈øoreknew. That is, whom God did prede≈øtinate, he ca≈øts none of them away, none of them ≈øhall peri≈øh. Many more Scriptures I might multiply, to ≈øhew, that a man once elected, can never peri≈øh; as 2 Tim. 2.19. 1 Cor. 1.8, 9. 2 The≈ø. 3.3. But I would name rea≈øons as well as Scriptures. And,

Fir≈øt, if Election were changeable, then God mu≈øt be changeable; which to think, there is nothing more ab≈øurd. If Gods decree be changeable, Gods e≈ø≈øence and nature were ≈øo al≈øo; election being nothing el≈øe, but God him≈øelfe chu≈øing: for every thing in God, is God. And this the Scripture tels us, is farre from him; for there is no variablene≈ø≈øe or ≈øhadow of change in God. Jam. 1.17. I≈øa. 46.10. Mal. 3.6.

Secondly, if the elect could peri≈øh, then Je≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhould be very unfaithfull to his father, becau≈øe God the father hath given this charge to Chri≈øt, that whom≈øoever he elected, Chri≈øt ≈øhould pre≈øerve them ≈øafe, to bring them to heaven. Now ≈øhould not this be accompli≈øhed, Chri≈øt would be unfaithfull to his father. John 6.39. This is the fathers will, which hath ≈øent me into the world, that of all that he hath given me, I ≈øhould lo≈øe nothing, but that I ≈øhould rai≈øe them up at the la≈øt day. This is the will of God, to ≈øave many by Chri≈øt. Now, ≈øhould not this be made good, Chri≈øt mu≈øt needs be unfaithfull to the Commi≈ø≈øion of his father.

Thirdly, ≈øhould this be true, then Pauls golden chaine ≈øhould be broken. Rom. 8.30. Whom he did prede≈øtinate, them he calls; whom he calls, them he ju≈øtifies; whom he ju≈øtifies, them he glorifies. Now, ≈øhould this chain break, that whom he elects, them he calls, whom he calls, them he ju≈øtifies, and there cea≈øe (as the Papi≈øts hold) and men be after damned, then the great and many links would be lo≈øt, that whom he ju≈øtifies, them he glorifies, and ≈øo bring an ab≈øurdity upon the Scripture thereby.

Now to an≈øwer ≈øome texts of Scripture they abu≈øe, (which at fir≈øt view you would think very plau≈øible) to maintain, that a man may be an elect man, and brought into Chri≈øt, yet afterward damned. The fir≈øt is, John 6.70. Have not I cho≈øen
twelve, and one of them is a divell? Now ≈øay they, there were twelve cho≈øen, or elected, and one of them is a divel, did peri≈øh, intimating, that men may be elected, yet peri≈øh for all this. To which I an≈øwer.

That there is a double electing. Fir≈øt, a chu≈øing to ≈øome peculiar Office. Secondly, there is an electing to grace, life, and glory. Now, when Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Have not I cho≈øen you twelve? it is meant of his chu≈øing of them to an Office, to the place of an Apo≈øtle, to be his di≈øciples. Now it is true, that man may be cho≈øen to ≈øome peculiar office in the Church of God, and yet be a peri≈øhing and damned man; but this phra≈øe hath no relation to the decree of God from eternity, onely to a temporall electing of twelve men to a temporall Office, to the Office of an Apo≈øtle.

Another Scripture they abu≈øe is, Exod. 32.32. it was Mo≈øes prayer, If thou wilt not (≈øaith Mo≈øes to God) forgive their ≈øinnes, then blot my name out of the book of life. Now, ≈øay they, the book of life is Gods election: and here Mo≈øes prayed, that God would blot his name out of the book of life. Intimating, ≈øay they, a man may be elected and written in that book, and yet afterward blotted out and peri≈øh?

To which I an≈øwer. That this prayer of Mo≈øes is onely a wi≈øh or ≈øuppo≈øition, as Pauls was, when he wi≈øht he were accur≈øed from Chri≈øt, for his kindred in the fle≈øh. Now a man may ≈øuppo≈øe mountaines of Gold, and ≈øuppo≈øe things that never were, nor ever ≈øhall be in being: bare ≈øuppo≈øitions put nothing in being; ≈øo here, that Mo≈øes makes a ≈øuppo≈øition in a patheticall prayer; this doth no way argue, as if his name could be blotted out of the book of life.

Secondly Rivet he expounds it thus, that there is a double book of life. The book of life being ≈øometimes taken for the eternall coun≈øell and decree of God, as Phil. 4.3. ≈øometimes for the ≈øpeciall providence of God over men, in pre≈øerving them among the living. So we read P≈øal. 139. In thy book, ≈øaith David, were all my members written: meaning, not in the book of Gods decree, but onely in the book of his providence, that all the members of Davids body, they were all
under the providence of God, that none could hurt him. And ≈øo Rivet, with others, think that by the book of life here is meant, that God would blot out Mo≈øes from the book of his ≈øpeciall protection, and let him die as other men, rather then this evil ≈øhould come upon the people of I≈ørael. q. d. De≈øtroy my name from among men, and doe not protect me any longer.

Againe, they object that in P≈øal. 69.28. It is ≈øaid, Let them be blotted out of the book of life. Now, ≈øay they, That is Gods election, and to be blotted out implies, that a man may be elected, and yet peri≈øh.

To this I an≈øwer, as formerly, that the book of life in that place hath no reference to the decree of Gods election, but onely to his book of providence, that God would not protect wicked men, as he doth his own people, in a way of providence. And other phra≈øes in Scripture will ≈øomewhat favour this interpretation. As Ezek. 13.9. They ≈øhall not be written in the writings of the hou≈øe of I≈ørael. Whats that? i.e. let them not any more be thought I≈øraelites, nor numbred among the people. And Ain≈øworth, I remember compares P≈øal. 69.19. with this place in Ezek. 13.9. and he makes the ≈øence to be one and the ≈øame; that to be blotted out of the book of life, is nothing el≈øe, then to be out of Gods protection; to be blotted out of the catalogue of the living, and have ones life in danger to be brought to death. And this wi≈øh David wi≈øhed for tho≈øe wicked men.

But then they object further from Revel. 22.19. If any man ≈øhall take away from the words of this book, God ≈øhall take away his part in the book of life. Here, ≈øay they, by book of life, is unque≈øtionably meant, Gods decree; and the Scripture ≈øaith, they that take any thing from this booke, God will blot him out of the book of life, and will undoubtedly damne him.

To which I an≈øwer. I confe≈ø≈øe in this place the book of life is taken for Gods decree; and that a man may be ≈øaid to be blotted out of this book, and yet this no way follow, that a man elected may be damned. And here, let me give you Au≈øtins words upon the place, which is a very cleare and ≈øati≈øfactory an≈øwer. That a man may be ≈øaid to be blotted out of
the book of life in two regards: Fir≈øt, it is equivalent to this phra≈øe, that his name ≈øhall never be written in the book of life. And you have often ≈øuch phra≈øes in Scripture. As it is ≈øaid in Matthew. He that doth evill him≈øelfe, and teacheth men ≈øo to doe, he ≈øhall be lea≈øt in the Kingdome of Heaven. Intimating, not as if he ≈øhould come to heaven, but that he ≈øhould not come there at all. To be lea≈øt there, is never to be there. So here, To be blotted out is equivalent to this, that they were never in.

Secondly, a mans name may be ≈øaid to be blotted out of the book of life, not as if it were there in deed and in truth, but in their own opinion; they thought they were elected, and thought their names were written there, they had ≈øtrong conceits of this; and though they are now deluded, and mi≈øtaken, yet God will make them know one day, when they are in hell, that their names are blotted out of the book of life. Again,

Another Scripture they abu≈øe is, 1 Cor. 10.12. Let him that thinks he ≈øtands, take heed le≈øt he fall. Now, ≈øay they, if it were not po≈ø≈øible for a man elected to fall, and fall finally, to what end is this caution of the Apo≈øtle? it were a needle≈ø≈øe caution, were it not po≈ø≈øible to come to pa≈ø≈øe.

To which I an≈øwer two things. Fir≈øt, the Apo≈øtle doth not ≈øay, Let him that ≈øtands, take heed le≈øt, &c. but the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, Let him that thinks he ≈øtands, take heed le≈øt he fall. Intimating, that men that think they are elected, and think they are in a good condition, they ≈øhould take heed, le≈øt they mi≈øcarry to all eternity.

Secondly, Take heed le≈øt they fall. This falling here is not meant, a falling from grace finally, and falling into hell, and peri≈øhing; but the falling here is onely a falling into ≈øinne, and ≈øo an elect man ≈øhould doe. An elect man, though he ≈øtand firm in Gods decree, yet he ≈øhould take heed all the daies of his life, that he fall not into ≈øinne. And if you aske me, how I make that appeare, I an≈øwer, from the context. This is a conclu≈øion, or caution the Apo≈øtle gives upon the enumeration of ≈øeverall in≈øtances of the people of God, that
in former ages did ≈øinne again≈øt God. As ≈øome that tempted Chri≈øt, and ≈øell in one day 23000. Others that fell to fornication, and provoked him in the wilderne≈ø≈øe. With many ≈øuch ≈øins reckoned up, and the ≈øumme of all is this, that ≈øeeing they that were Gods people fell into ≈øinne, and were puni≈øhed, therefore you that think you ≈øtand, and think you are elected, you ≈øhould take heed you fall not into ≈øinne, as they did. And thus I have done with re≈øolving this ≈øecond query.

Thirdly, whether doth God elect any man to life and ≈øalvation upon fore≈øight of his faith or good works? fore≈øeeing that this man will believe, therefore I elect him to ≈øalvation; and the other man doth not believe, therefore I chu≈øe him to damnation. Whether, I ≈øay, doth God in his eternall decree elect any man to life, upon fore≈øight of works. Here the Papi≈øts and Arminians joyne both together in maintaining of this. The rea≈øon, ≈øay they, why God elects ≈øome, and not others, is becau≈øe God did fore≈øee from eternity that that man would be holy, and would believe in Chri≈øt, and therefore God elected him to ≈øalvation. The≈øe are the hard imputations they lay to Gods charge.

And in the re≈øolving of this, I ≈øhall an≈øwer it in the Negative. That God, in electing a certain number of men to life and ≈øalvation, did not doe it upon the fore≈øight of any good works he ≈øaw would be in them; whether Faith, Repentance, ≈øanctification, or any other grace. Indeed it is true, the Papi≈øts many of them doe not gro≈øly ≈øay, that it was fore≈øight of good works in generall, but the fore≈øight of faith only, and ≈øo the Arminians.

But now, to overthrow this ungrounded opinion, Fir≈øt, I ≈øhall lay down Scriptures to confirm this, that God in electing of men to ≈øalvation, doth not doe it upon fore≈øight of good workes, and then lay down rea≈øons; and after that take tho≈øe objections, which ≈øeem to darken this truth.

Fir≈øt, for the Scriptures that confirm this, we have Rom. 11.5. He hath ≈øaved a remnant according to the election of grace. Intimating, that the remnant that are ≈øaved, it is onely of grace, not of fore≈øeen works. So Eph. 1.5, 11. He hath elected
us according to the good plea≈øure of his own will. Gods meere good will was the impul≈øive cau≈øe of mans election, and nothing in man. So likewi≈øe, Rom. 9.11. That Gods election might ≈øtand, not according to our works, but according to the good plea≈øure of him that called us. So 2 Tim. 1.9. Not of works, but according to his own purpo≈øe and grace. Upon his good plea≈øure, and his good will to mankind, upon that ground election ≈øtands.
But now to adde ≈øome rea≈øons, why it cannot be that God ≈øhould determine in his own coun≈øell, to ≈øave man upon the fore≈øight of his works. I ≈øhall name three or foure. As,

Fir≈øt, becau≈øe the inferiour priviledges that God be≈øtows upon his people, as vocation, and ju≈øtification (though they are in actuall being) are not for their good works, therefore much le≈ø≈øe is election for good works onely fore≈øeen. Fir≈øt, for Vocation, 2 Tim. 1.19. We are called, not according to our own works, but according to the purpo≈øe of his own grace. And then for ju≈øtification, we are not ju≈øtified for works neither. Rom. 3.34. We are ju≈øtified freely by his grace, for by the works of the law ≈øhall no fle≈øh be ju≈øtified. Now, if vocation and ju≈øtification be not for works, much le≈ø≈øe is election for works, and for works fore≈øeen, not in being in us.

Secondly, becau≈øe then it would follow, that children, dying in infancy could not be elected ‚Ä¢ for the child being in the mothers wombe, if it hath life, it hath a ≈øoule, and ≈øo mu≈øt either be ≈øaved, or damned. But a child, while it is in the womb, neither acts good or evill. Now if God did elect per≈øons to life, upon fore≈øight of works, then children dying in the wombe could not be elected; becau≈øe there are no works God could fore≈øee in them. And then this would be a very uncomfortable doctrine for parents, that have children dying young.

Thirdly, then would man have ≈øomewhat whereof to boa≈øt before his God, as if he could lay claime to ≈øalvation from him. If God were bound to choo≈øe men to ≈øalvation upon fore≈øight of good works, then man might ≈øay, I thank not God, but I thank my believing, and thank my good works,
for the≈øe were the motives for which he cho≈øe me to glory; and thus would poore man boa≈øt again≈øt his Maker.

Fourthly, Becau≈øe God hath elected the wor≈øt of men; when others that have more naturall worth and goodne≈ø≈øe are pa≈ø≈øed by. 1 Cor. 1.27, 28. God hath cho≈øen the fooli≈øh things of the world to confound the wi≈øe, and God hath cho≈øen the weake things of the world, &c. and ba≈øe things of the world, and things that are de≈øpi≈øed hath God cho≈øen, &c. And Matth. 11.25. I thank thee, O Father, that thou ha≈øt hid the≈øe things from the wi≈øe and prudent, and ha≈øt revealed them unto babes. Tho≈øe that had the greate≈øt worldly wi≈ødome, and naturall abilities, that mo≈øt excelled in outward ≈øtrictne≈ø≈øe, and morall vertues, are rejected, when tho≈øe that are but babes in under≈øtanding, who many times are the wor≈øt for their moralities, are elected; which is a cleare demon≈øtration, that election is not grounded upon faith, or works fore≈øeen; for then the be≈øt had been cho≈øen before the re≈øt.

Fifthly, Our works carry no proportion to what God hath elected us unto; we are elected to eternall glory, but our works are finite, imperfect, no more then our duty; yea not done by our own ≈øtrength, but by the power of Gods grace, and therefore cannot be that which moveth God to elect us.
Sixthly, becau≈øe God doth not chu≈øe men to life for the ≈øake of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, therefore much le≈ø≈øe for their works ≈øake.

It is true, and mi≈øtake me not, I confe≈ø≈øe, (and ≈øo all Divines that are confe≈ø≈øe this) that God ≈øaves a man for Chri≈øts ≈øake, but God elects not a man for Chri≈øts ≈øake, but meerly for his own good plea≈øures ≈øake. God in chu≈øing a man to life, hath no reference to Chri≈øt, as if Chri≈øt were the motive. Chri≈øt was prede≈øtinated him≈øelfe, therefore could not be the cau≈øe of our prede≈øtination, 1 Pet. 1.20. We are cho≈øen in him its true, Eph. 1.4. as the common per≈øon; God elected Chri≈øt fir≈øt in order, and all believers in him, but it is not for Chri≈øts ≈øake, but according to his own will. As ≈øuppo≈øe a Kingdome to be newly ≈øet up, a King is cho≈øen, and his ≈øucce≈ø≈øors to follow after; why then all the ≈øucceeding Kings are cho≈øen in him that was fir≈øt elected: ≈øo are we cho≈øen in Chri≈øt. God
doth chu≈øe a man as freely, as if Chri≈øt did never die; and yet God ≈øaves none, but for Chri≈øts ≈øaxe; and this makes election on Gods part mo≈øt free. God doth not con≈øider Chri≈øt, nor the good works we have, but tis onely his own good will engages him to ≈øave ≈øome, and neglect others. And thus much for proving this point. There are ≈øome objections now that lie in the way, which mu≈øt be removed.

God, ≈øay they, doth elect men upon the fore≈øight of their good works; and they alledge foure Scriptures to prove this. James 2.2 Hath not God cho≈øen the poore of this world to be rich in faith? now, ≈øay they, their laying out their e≈øtates for good u≈øes, and ≈øo becomming poore, that is the rea≈øon why God chu≈øeth them, and neglects richer men.

To which I an≈øwer. That poore here is onely ≈øpoken of, Dins elegit ≈øideles us ≈øi ‚Ä¢ t non quia jam ‚Ä¢ rant. Aug. l. de praede≈øt. as the quality of the per≈øons that are cho≈øen, not as the cau≈øe wherefore they are cho≈øen. And this an≈øwer Mr. Perkins gives: that poverty is not the cau≈øe why, but the de≈øcription of the per≈øons that are cho≈øen; that Gods decree of election doth commonly runne among the poorer ≈øort of men, the more to advance his own grace; that man ≈øhall not ≈øay, election is intailed upon works: for if poverty ≈øhould be the cau≈øe of their election, then all that are poore ≈øhould be elected, which is fal≈øe. Again further they object,

2 The≈ø. 2.13. God from the beginning hath cho≈øen us to ≈øalvation, through ≈øanctification of the Spirit, and beliefe of the truth. Now ≈øay they, ≈øanctification, and faith is made as the channel, through which election mu≈øt run, and therefore that is the cau≈øe or motive why God did elect them. To this we an≈øwer.

That it is true, God elects men through ≈øanctification and faith, as the end God aimes at in elect per≈øons, not as the motive for which he elects them. And this an≈øwer Rivet gives. All elect men ≈øhall be ≈øanctified, and all elect men ≈øhall believe; though it is not for this ≈øanctification and beliefe that they are elected. It is not for grace, but unto grace they are cho≈øen. This di≈øtinction the Scripture gives, 1 Pet. 1.2. Ye are elect according to the foreknowl dge of God, through ≈øanctification unto obedience. Not for, as the motive; but to, as the end.
Again, Titus 1.1. it is called the faith of Gods elect. Now, ≈øay they, it is called ≈øo, becau≈øe God elects them fore≈øeeing their faith. To which we an≈øwer.

That faith is here called, the faith of Gods elect; not as if God fore≈øeeing faith did elect men; but becau≈øe all elect men ≈øhall believe, becau≈øe faith is a peculiar priviledge belonging onely to elect men, therefore it is called their faith.

And then la≈øtly, one Scripture more they alledge, 2 Tim. 2.20. If any man ≈øhall purge him≈øelf from ≈øin, he ≈øhall be a ve≈ø≈øell of honour. Now here, ≈øay they, purging, that is, ≈øanctification, and good works, it is made a condition of election, of being a ve≈ø≈øell of honour. God makes this condition, if he for≈øee a man will purge him≈øelfe, and will live holily, that man ≈øhall be elected, ≈øhall be a ve≈ø≈øell of honour. To which we give this an≈øwer, That purging and ≈øanctification is here laid down, not as the cau≈øe, but as the ≈øigne of their election; not as the cau≈øe why men are ve≈ø≈øels of honour, but the ≈øigne or evidence that they are ≈øo. If you are purged, you ≈øhall be ve≈ø≈øels of honour; that is, if you are ≈øanctified, it is a ≈øign to you, that you are elected.

div.head: SERMON XV.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p: THe la≈øt Conclu≈øion or Doctrine drawn from the≈øe words, was this, That Chri≈øtians ≈øhould put forth a great deale of diligence to make this ≈øure to their ≈øoules, that they are eternally elected by God to life and glory. In the pro≈øecution of which I have di≈øpatched ≈øeverall queries. I am now to proceed further in the di≈øpatch of what yet remaines to be ≈øpoken concerning this ≈øubject. A fourth query followes.

Q. Fourthly, Whether the decree of election, or Gods purpo≈øe to ≈øave a company of men, being from eternity, and being immutable, whether doth not this give way to man to be ≈øecure, and carele≈ø≈øe in the u≈øe of the means of grace, that they take no care to get grace, and to get heaven, while they are in the world? This is a very u≈øefull point to in≈øi≈øt upon, ≈øeeing the Arminians charge us with this, that if we hold election without re≈øpect to Gods fore≈øight of workes in men, then this layes open a gap for men to live as they li≈øt, that they ≈øhall ≈øay, If God hath determined they ≈øhall be ≈øaved, they ≈øhall be ≈øaved; if that they ≈øhall be damned, they ≈øhall be damned, whether they are holy, or profane; if God hath elected them to life, they ≈øhall be ≈øaved, let them live as they li≈øt. Thus the Arminians plead. This therefore is the query, whether this doctrine of election doth admini≈øter any ground for ≈øuch a cavill as this to be in the minds of men?

To an≈øwer which, I ≈øhall fir≈øt lay down this generall Conclu≈øion, That the decree, or the purpo≈øe of God about the
election of man to life and ≈øalvation, doth no way admini≈øter any ju≈øt ground to men, to make them live as they li≈øt, and to make them neglect the means of grace and ≈øalvation. In the clearing of which, I ≈øhall lay down three particulars, to ≈øatisfie you about this matter. As,

Fir≈øt, that Gods decree about Civill and Temporall matters, doth no way give encouragement to men to neglect the u≈øe of means, and live carele≈ø≈øe of the accompli≈øhment of his decree; and therefore not ≈øo in ≈øpirituall. As now for in≈øtance: God hath determined from all eternity, how long every one of us ≈øhall live in the world; our daies are numbred in his coun≈øell. Now, though God hath determined how long we ≈øhall live, this no way gives us encouragement to ≈øay therefore I will never put on a rag of cloathes to cover me in Winter, and I will never put a mor≈øell of meat in my mouth; for God hath determined how long I ≈øhall live, and therefore whether I eate or no, till then I ≈øhall not die. Again, God hath determined from all eternity, touching every one of us, whether we ≈øhall be poore or rich in this world, and therefore to draw this conclu≈øion, that it is no matter whether I be indu≈øtrious in following my calling, and looking after my trade, or whether I ≈øpend my e≈øtate in rioting and drunkenne≈ø≈øe; God hath determined whether I ≈øhall be rich or poore; if he hath decreed I ≈øhall be poore, I ≈øhall be poore; or that I ≈øhall be rich, I ≈øhall be rich, let me live as I plea≈øe: this rea≈øoning is very fond and fooli≈øh in Temporall things, therefore much more in Spirituall. God hath determined from all eternity whether thou ≈øhalt be ≈øaved or damned, and the decree of God cannot be changed; but now to draw hence, that it is no matter how I live, whether in waies of holine≈ø≈øe, or in waies of ≈øinne, this is an abu≈øive collection from Gods decree. Becau≈øe, as Dr. Pre≈øton ≈øaith, if a man doth not u≈øe tho≈øe means that may evidence to his ≈øoule that he is elected, it is an argument he is not elected. If thou ≈øay, if God hath determined it, he will ≈øave me, whether I am holy or prophane, and therefore I will never heare Sermon, never pray in my family, never u≈øe holy duties; Saith Pre≈øton, if
thou neglect the≈øe means, it is an argument thou art not elected; becau≈øe, as God hath elected thee to the end, he hath al≈øo ordained thee to u≈øe the means. I have read a ≈øtory of an Italian, who lying upon his death-bed, ≈øent for a Phy≈øician, the mo≈øt exqui≈øite and exact Arti≈øt in all Italy; and this man held this opinion I am now ≈øpeaking of, that ≈øeeing Gods decrees were unalterable, a man might live as he li≈øt, and yet be ≈øaved; that let a man be as holy as he could be, if God had decreed his damnation, he ≈øhould be damned; and let a man be never ≈øo wicked, if God have decreed his ≈øalvation, hee ≈øhould be ≈øaved; and that the decree of God tooke off the u≈øe of all means, that a man need not u≈øe any meanes, but onely tru≈øt in God. The Phy≈øician being a man acquainted in the my≈øteries of Religion, after he had asked him the ≈øtate of his body, and where the di≈øea≈øe lay, the party de≈øiring him to pre≈øcribe ≈øome phi≈øick, the Phi≈øician gave him this an≈øwer: ≈øaith he, God hath determined how long you ≈øhall live; therefore, if I give you phy≈øick, if God hath determined you ≈øhall die, you ≈øhall die for all that; and if he hath decreed you ≈øhall live, though I give you no phy≈øick, yet you ≈øhall live. And this an≈øwer (≈øaith the Hi≈øtorian) took ≈øuch place with the Italian, that it converted him in this very principle, and he became a man very diligent in following the means of grace, upon this very ≈øaying. And indeed, a ju≈øt & grounded ≈øpeech it is. This therefore is my fir≈øt an≈øwer, that if ≈øuch rea≈øonings as the≈øe in temporall things are unrea≈øonable, they are much more in ≈øpirituall.

Secondly, to you that make this plea, I would ≈øay this: That at that very ≈øame in≈øtant wherein God did decree or determine to bring any man to life, at that very in≈øtant God did decree likewi≈øe that that man ≈øhould be holy before hee died; he ≈øhall u≈øe all ≈øanctified and holy means conducible to his ≈øalvation. Rom. 8.29. Whom he did prede≈øtinate, them he did prede≈øtinate to be conformable to the Image of his ≈øonne. God the Father, in that very decree wherein he did ordain man to life, did ordaine, that tho≈øe men elected ≈øhould live conformable to Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Ephe≈ø. 1.4. He hath cho≈øen us in Chri≈øt,
before the foundation of the world was laid, that we ≈øhould be holy and blamele≈ø≈øe before him in love. God did decree, that our lives ≈øhould be holy; he ordaines holine≈ø≈øe as the means, as well as heaven as the end. So Ephe≈ø. 2.10. God hath created us in Chri≈øt Je≈øus unto good works, which he hath before ordained, that we ≈øhould walke in them. 2 The≈ø. 2.13. God, before the world was, at that very in≈øtant wherein he ordained, and cho≈øe men to life, did al≈øo ordaine, that men ≈øhould live a holy and blamele≈ø≈øe life here upon earth. Now then, for men to make this objection, that ≈øeeing God hath decreed men to life, therefore men may live as they li≈øt, is ab≈øurd: for if men doe live as they li≈øt, it is an argument God did not decree them to life, becau≈øe God in decreeing men to life and ≈øalvation, did decree they ≈øhould walk in a cour≈øe of ≈øanctification, and holy living in this world.

Thirdly, ≈øuppo≈øe this ≈øhould be taken for granted, that God had decreed to damne thee or me; that God in his purpo≈øe had appointed he would not ≈øave us; yet God, as a Creator, de≈øerves thy ≈øervice. God, as Creator, may lay claime to thy duties. Though God ≈øhould condemne us, yet he making us, de≈øerves obedience, and de≈øerves duties of thankfulne≈ø≈øe from us. And therefore, under this notion onely, though no other con≈øideration be looked after, this ≈øhould engage you to righteous living; and this ≈øhould engage you in a way of duties, though he never ≈øave you. Adam, though he never ≈øhould come to heaven, being in innocency, yet being made and created by God, was engaged to live a holy life. And ≈øo it is with every man alive, as we are creatures, and have a being from God, and the comforts of this life from God, all this doth oblige us to a cour≈øe of obedience, and righteous living toward God, though he ≈øhould throw us into hell, when we have done. And thus much for re≈øolving the fourth Query, that the decree of God touching mans election to life, doth no way give encouragement to men to live as they li≈øt, upon the forementioned grounds. I now pa≈ø≈øe to the fifth Query.

Fifthly, what temptations doth the divell ≈øugge≈øt into the minds of godly men, to make them doubt within them≈øelves,
that they are not elected by God, when indeed they are, to make them thinke they are reprobate ≈øilver, when they are ve≈ø≈øels of honour, meet for their Ma≈øters u≈øe? Happily I may ≈øpeak to ≈øome, who≈øe ≈øpirits are perplexed in this ca≈øe. And the an≈øwer hereunto, I ≈øhall reduce to three heads, and as I lay them down, labour to take them off, that they may be no ju≈øt ground or rea≈øon to make you doubt of your election.

Fir≈øt, the divell tempts a godly man with this, that ≈øure you cannot be elected, Becau≈øe that before your calling you were ≈øo exceeding ≈øinfull and profane in your lives; ≈øo exceedingly profane, vile, wicked livers, that certainly (the divel will ≈øay) ≈øuch as you could not fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods purpo≈øe to ≈øave.

Secondly, the divell will tell you, that certainly you cannot be elected to life, becau≈øe that after your calling into Je≈øus Chri≈øt, you have fallen ≈øo fouly into capitall, and ≈øcandalous crimes and ≈øinnes.

And thirdly, becau≈øe that God doth continually pur≈øue his people with outward and great afflictions; thence the divell will gather, you are not the cho≈øen and beloved of God. The≈øe three grand temptations he doth many times fa≈øten upon many tender con≈øciences, meerly to create a world of doubts and perplexities in the cho≈øen ve≈ø≈øels of mercy. I begin with the fir≈øt.

Fir≈øt, the divell tempts you, that ≈øure you are not elected, becau≈øe your lives were ≈øo exceedingly profane, and you were ≈øuch abominable ill livers, before you tooke upon you the profe≈ø≈øion of Je≈øus Chri≈øt; this the divell layes before many a poore ≈øoule to ≈øtumble at.
To ≈øatisfie you in this therefore, I ≈øhall lay down four particulars by way of an≈øwer.

Fir≈øt, Many of the ≈øervants of God before their calling, have been very lewd, wicked, notorious, profane livers, and yet have been within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election to life and glory. Ca≈øt your eyes upon Paul, and there you ≈øhall finde what he was before his call. He tels you him≈øelfe, I was a blu≈øphemer, (a horrible ≈øinne) I was a per≈øecuter, I was injurious
to God Church. I haled men to pri≈øon for profe≈ø≈øing the name of Je≈øus. (The≈øe are great ≈øinnes.) Nay further, ≈øaith he, I was exceeding mad again≈øt the Church of God. A man enraged with malice again≈øt the people of God. Now what could be morvile then the≈øe? And yet you ≈øhall finde this man, a cho≈øen ve≈ø≈øell of mercy. Nay, you ≈øhall finde, God to ≈øtrengthen the confidence of men upon their election, puts a ≈øcandalous liver and election together, to make men ≈øee, that a ≈øcandalous life before conver≈øion, is no prejudice to a mans election. Acts 9.13, 14. And Ananias ≈øaid, Lord, we have heard of this man by many (≈øpeaking of Paul) how much evill he hath done to thy Saints at Hieru≈øalem. We have heard by many what an evill man this is, and that he hath authority from the chiefe P ‚Ä¢ ie≈øts to binde all that call upon thy Name; and that this man did doe it, did execute his commi≈ø≈øion; here was a wicked liver: but now mark what the Lord ≈øaith, Goe thy way, for he is a cho≈øen ve≈ø≈øell to me. Here you ≈øee Ananias laies his offence, and his wickedne≈ø≈øe before him; and yet, Goe thy way, ≈øaith God: Goe thy way, for he is a cho≈øen ve≈ø≈øell to me. The like in≈øtances we have in Mana≈ø≈øeth and Mary Magdalen. This therefore is my fir≈øt an≈øwer, that many of the ≈øervants of God have been men of very ill and notorious lives, before conver≈øion, and yet they have been within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election to ≈øalvation.

Secondly, though men have been notoriou≈øly wicked, in their lives before calling, yet if this notorious wickedne≈ø≈øe doth lay an engagement upon them, to make them labour to be more eminent in grace after calling; this is rather a ≈øigne of election, then reprobation. It is ob≈øervable in Paul, he was a notorious wicked man before his call; but now this exceeding wickedne≈ø≈øe of his before his call, did engage him to labour to exceed all others in goodne≈ø≈øe after he was converted, and the more evill he was before, the more holy he labours to be after. As he laboured before to hale men to pri≈øon for profe≈ø≈øing Je≈øus Chri≈øt, he is now as zealous to draw men to Je≈øus Chri≈øt after his call; he was very indu≈øtrious to doe evill before his call, and this made him after his call, as he
≈øaith him≈øelfe, I was in labours more abundant then they all. And ≈øo Mary Magdalen, who before her calling was a vile woman, one that was a common harlot; a woman out of whom Je≈øus Chri≈øt ca≈øt ≈øeven divels; and yet this woman, after her calling, ≈øhe laboured to be more eminent in godly ≈øorrow, then any woman before or ≈øince; ≈øhe wa≈øhed Chri≈øts feet with her teares, and wiped them with the haires of her head. The like of which you do not read of any woman in Scripture. And this was a very good ≈øigne; when your notoriou≈øne≈ø≈øe in waies of ≈øinne before calling, ≈øhall lay ≈øuch an engagement upon you to become more eminent in grace after calling; this is a very good encouragement or evidence that you are within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election; and therefore you have no cau≈øe to be di≈øcouraged. Suppo≈øe before the word laid hold upon your con≈øcience, you were guilty of filthy ≈øinnes, not fit to be named in the congregation; if you will the more honour God, and prai≈øe God now, and walk more humbly, and labour to excell each other in grace now, as you did in ≈øinne in times pa≈øt. This is a great ≈øigne that you are in the company of Gods Elect ones.

Thirdly, you that have been ≈øcandalous in your lives before calling, for your comfort know, that God in his eternall coun≈øell doth commonly make the profane and wicked and the wor≈øt of men, the objects of his election, rather then civill hone≈øt men, rather then men that are of an hone≈øt and civill, and morall conver≈øation here in this world. And the Lord doth it upon this ground, the more to magnifie the freene≈ø≈øe, and the riches of his own grace in electing men to life. For ≈øhould God onely chu≈øe moderate and civill hone≈øt men in the world, men would be apt to think it is that mans morality, and that mans civility, that was the motive which provoked God to elect them; and therefore God, to overthrow the≈øe thoughts, he lets election runne rather unto men that have been notoriou≈øly gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øinfull in their lives, then other men; Mana≈ø≈øeh a notorious bloudy man, yet falls within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, when many a
civill man is left out. Mary, a common harlot, yet cho≈øen, when many a mode≈øt cha≈øte woman was ca≈øt into hell. Matth. 21.31, 32. There Chri≈øt urgeth a parable of two men. One that ≈øaid he would go and follow Chri≈øt, but did not; and the other ≈øaid he would not goe, but did; now which of the≈øe twaine did the will of Chri≈øt? and they ≈øaid, the fir≈øt. And Je≈øus ≈øaid unto them, Verily I ≈øay unto you, that publicans and harlots ≈øhall goe into heaven before you. But you will ≈øay, was this common? this was onely one ≈øingle time: therefore mark the next words, For John came to you in the way of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and you believed not; but the publicans and harlots believed in Chri≈øt. John came preaching, and you would not believe, you Phari≈øees, ≈øtrict morall men, that did not flie out into ≈øuch ≈øcandals as other men did, you would not believe, ≈øaith Chri≈øt, but Publicans, men that were mo≈øt addicted to extortion, and uncon≈øcionable gaine, they imbraced Je≈øus Chri≈øt, when morall men would not. This therefore ≈øhould be another comfort for you, that many times election runnes rather to the profaner ≈øort of men, then to men that are civill and righteous dealing men here in the world; and this God doth to magnifie the riches of his own grace.

Fourthly, that it is no matter what you were before your calling, ≈øo you are a repentant and holy people after; your former mi≈øcarriages ≈øhall no way prejudice your future ble≈ø≈øedne≈ø≈øe. 1 Cor. 6.9, 10, 11. Neither Fornicator, nor Idolater, nor Adulterer, nor envious, nor thiefe, nor covetous, nor reviler ≈øhall enter into the Kingdome of Heaven: and ≈øuch were ≈øome of you &c. Here you ≈øee a Catalogue of vile evils heaped together, and ≈øuch were ≈øome of you; but now you are wa≈øhed, now you are ≈øanctified, &c. So that no matter what you were before conver≈øion, though guilty of great ≈øinnes, ≈øo you are now a reformed people, now a ≈øanctified people, Titus 3.3. We our ≈øelves al≈øo were ≈øometimes fooli≈øh, di≈øobedient, deceived, ≈øerving divers lu≈øts and plea≈øures, and living in malice and envie, &c. You were ≈øo; but after the kindne≈ø≈øe and love of God appeared to you, after they were called and converted they were not ≈øo. So that the≈øe foure particulars will clearly take off this
objection, that no matter what you were before conver≈øion, if you are now a repentant people, and bewaile your evils, and reform your waies, your former ill led life will be no hindrance at all to your election. Indeed this I mu≈øt needs ≈øay, that you that have been mo≈øt notorious in ≈øinne, God expects this at your hands, that you be mo≈øt eminent in grace, mo≈øt deep in humiliation, mo≈øt eminent in godly ≈øorrow, though your former evills doe no way prejudice your election.

Secondly, if the divell cannot fa≈øten this upon you, he will come upon you with this a≈ø≈øault, viz. your frequent falling into ≈øcandalous and foule, and gro≈ø≈øe enormities, after you took upon you a profe≈ø≈øion of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. And this the divell will lay clo≈øe: happily ≈øinne before conver≈øion was not ≈øo great; but now ≈øince you have followed Sermons, and ≈øince you have profe≈ø≈øed Je≈øus Chri≈øt, ≈øince that time you have fallen foulely into gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandalous ≈øinnes, and ≈øurely this is incon≈øi≈øtent with grace, and cannot befall per≈øons within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election.
And I confe≈ø≈øe this is both ≈øad and hazardous: yet I ≈øhall lay down three things to uphold thee, that yet for all this thou mai≈øt be within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election. As,

Fir≈øt, that divers per≈øons who were within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, have fallen foulely into gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes after their call. Lot, after he was called, fell to be ince≈øtuous, and fell to drunkenne≈ø≈øe; David, after he was called, fell into Adultery; Peter, after he was called, fell to a deniall of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Yea, you read of Solomon, 1 Kings 11.9. That his heart was turned from the Lord, after the Lord had revealed him≈øelfe unto him twice. After God had revealed him≈øelfe to Solomon, and converted him; after that time he did evill again≈øt his God. Nay, you read further, Nehem. 13.26, 27. That Solomons wives turned away his heart from the Lord, though he was the beloved of his God. Though he were beloved by God, and were elected by him, yet his wives turned away his heart from the Lord. The like phra≈øe you have
Numb. 14.22. After all the≈øe great works, I have done amongst them, and the miracles I have ≈øhewn them in Aegypt, and in the Wilderne≈ø≈øe, they have provoked me, ≈øaith the Lord, the≈øe ten times. After they were the Lords by covenant, and after they were a delivered people; after this they provoked him many a time, by ≈øinning again≈øt him, and yet divers of them were elect ve≈ø≈øels of mercy. So that, I ≈øay, many of Gods ≈øervants after their calling, are fallen foulely into ≈øcandalous ≈øinnes, and yet have been within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election.

Secondly, if you falling into gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandalous ≈øinnes, have not the≈øe foure ≈øinfull ingredients, your falling into ≈øinne after calling, may be con≈øi≈øtent with election. Fir≈øt, if you fall not into ≈øinne voluntarily. Secondly, if you fall not into the ≈øame ≈øinne frequently. Thirdly, if you fall not into ≈øinne with complacency. And fourthly, if you lie not under your fall impenitently. If the≈øe ingredients be mixed with your ≈øinning after your call, they are incon≈øi≈øtent with election. Fir≈øt, if you fall into ≈øinne voluntarily, that you ru≈øh into ≈øinne, as a hor≈øe into the battell. Secondly, if you fall into the ≈øame ≈øinne frequently, then it is hazardous and dangerous. It is true Peter denied Chri≈øt, but it was but in one fit of a temptation. David fell into Adultery, but it was never but once; Lot was guilty of drunkenne≈ø≈øe, but onely in one fit: For the ≈øervants of God, though they fall, yet they fall not frequently into the ≈øame ≈øinne, if gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandalous. Thirdly, if you fall into ≈øinne with complacency, that you take plea≈øure in the evils you fall into; if you doe as Job ≈øaith, wallow ≈øinne under your tongue; counting it ≈øweet and delight≈øome to you. And la≈øtly, if all this be joyned with impenitency, that you have not a heart to repent of the evils you fal into, the Lord have mercy upon you; for certainly, if you fall into ≈øinne with the≈øe ingredients, you are not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods mercy to ≈øave. But now, though you doe fall into ≈øinne, if it be not voluntary, but through the force of temptation: if it be not with complacency, but a di≈ølike of the ≈øins you fall into; and as ≈øoon as
you doe fall, and ≈øee your ≈øinnes you repent and ri≈øe again, though you doe fall in this way, it will be no prejudice to your election.

Thirdly, falling into ≈øinne after calling and profe≈ø≈øion made of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, may be con≈øi≈øtent with election in the≈øe foure ca≈øes. Fir≈øt, if the ≈øinnes you fall into be clearly di≈øcerned. Secondly, if they are ≈øen≈øibly bewailed. Thirdly, if they are ≈øtrongly re≈øi≈øted; and la≈øtly, if they are daily laboured, and prayed again≈øt. Though you doe fall into ≈øinne, yet in the≈øe ca≈øes ≈øinne will not be damning to you, or be an impediment to your election. And thus I have done with the ≈øecond ca≈øe of con≈øcience. Onely, let me urge this one thing before I leave it, (for I would not have you make this doctrine a doctrine of liberty; but I would have you lay this to heart) that if any of you doe fall foulely, after conver≈øion; believe it, God will make you ≈ømart for this, though not in hell, yet you ≈øhall have a hell in your con≈øcience, you ≈øhall have the very pregu≈øtations of hell, a wounded con≈øcience, and God will expect deep humiliation, and great repentance, if you ≈øinne after profe≈ø≈øion made of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. It may have that influence upon you, as upon David, who cried out, I have no quietne≈ø≈øe in my bones, by rea≈øon of my ≈øinne. God will give you no re≈øt night nor day by rea≈øon of ≈øinne, if you runne into it after profe≈ø≈øion made of Je≈øus Chri≈øt.

Thirdly, men doe doubt of their election, becau≈øe God pur≈øues them with continuall afflictions, and layes the continued ≈øtrokes of his heavy wrath upon them; and this makes many a godly man thinke, that he is not in the number of Gods elect ones. To which I ≈øhall briefly an≈øwer.

That this is nothing el≈øe but a temptation, and not a truth; and it was the very controver≈øie that Jobs friends had with him; they would fa≈øten this upon Job, that he was a Reprobate, and an Hypocrite, becau≈øe God did ≈øo afflict him: yet Job maintained his ≈øincerity, and ≈øhewes his grounds, that God was his friend, and that he did not reject him, though he did afflict him. But to ≈øpeake more particularly.

Fir≈øt, no man can infallibly and certainly judge of Gods purpo≈øes about mans election, or reprobation, by any of the di≈øpen≈øations of God toward their bodies in the things of this life. Eccle≈ø. 9.1, 2. No man knows either love or hatred by any thing that is before him. All things fall alike to all. The ≈øame event to him that feareth God, and to him that feareth him not, to him that ≈øweareth, and to him that feareth an Oath.

Secondly, Afflictions from God are ≈øo farre from being grounds, or evidences that a man is not elected, that in ≈øome ca≈øes they may prove evidences that they are the very elect of God. Heb. 12.6, 7. He cha≈øteneth every ≈øonne whom he receiveth; they are ba≈øtards, and not ≈øonnes, whom he cha≈øti≈øeth not. As many as I love, I rebuke and cha≈øten, be zealous therefore and repent. Revel. 3.19. In ≈øome ca≈øes afflictions from God are rather tokens of love from God, then the contrary. As now, in ca≈øe afflictions be as a ≈øpur to you, to make you quicken your pace in heaven way. 2. In ca≈øe your afflictions be as pruning-hookes to you, to cut and lop off the luxuriant buddings, and workings of ≈øinne in the heart. 3. In ca≈øe affliction be as a hedge to you to keep you in, and to make you walke in a clo≈øe communion with God, and not to wander or goe a≈øtray from him. 4. In ca≈øe affliction be as a file to you, to file off that ru≈øt that cleaves to your nature. 5. In ca≈øe affliction proves a furnace to refine you from that dro≈ø≈øe of corruption that is mixt with your ≈øervices. In the≈øe ca≈øes afflictions are ≈øo farre from being grounds to doubt of your election, that they may rather give you evidence, you are the very elect of God.

Thirdly, that God in his wi≈ødome doth many times expo≈øe his own people to greater troubles in this life, then he lets wicked and reprobate men undergoe. God will not give reprobates their hell here, that ≈øo he might give them hell hereafter. God will not give the elect heaven here, to make heaven more de≈øirable to them, while they live here; and more welcome when they come there. It is Gods plea≈øure
in the di≈øpen≈øations of his providence among≈øt men, to let his own people lie under more outward ≈øorrows, then wicked men ≈øhall doe. P≈øal. 73.5. Their eyes bur≈øt out with fatne≈ø≈øe, they are not in trouble, as other men, neither are they plagued, as other men are. The Lord in his di≈øpen≈øations doth ≈øo deale with wicked men, that they are not plagued, they are not troubled, as godly men are in this world. And therefore ≈øurely affliction is no argument of Gods di≈øplea≈øure, or of their not being within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods purpo≈øe to doe them good.

div.head: SERMON XVI.

epigraph.q: Wherefore the rather, Brethren, give all diligence to make your Calling and Election ≈øure.

div.p: THe Doctrine I am yet upon is this, That Chri≈øtians ≈øhould put forth a great deale of diligence to make this ≈øure to their ≈øoules, that they are eternally elected by God to life and ≈øalvation. In the pro≈øecution of which Doctrine, I have gone over ≈øeverall particulars; and have now only one Querie more to ≈øatisfie about election; and then to winde up this Doctrine, in laying down ≈øome explicatory propo≈øitions, very conducible to illu≈øtrate this Doctrine of Election. And the Quere to be re≈øolved is this.

What are tho≈øe delu≈øions of the divell whereby he nouri≈øheth pre≈øumptuous per≈øwa≈øions in the minds of men, that they are elected by God, when they are not? And to an≈øwer this, I ≈øhall reduce all I have to ≈øay under the≈øe three heads.

Fir≈øt, the divell per≈øwades wicked men that they are elected, upon this ground. Becau≈øe they doe not break forth into ≈øuch gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandalous enormities in their lives, as many men that live about them doe: and therefore the divell boul≈øters them up in this, Surely if you were not elected, you would be as bad as any, and as vile and exorbitant as any. Now ≈øeeing God keepes you in, that you act not ≈øuch things in your lives, as other men doe; this may be a comfortable evidence to you, that you are in the number of Gods elect ones. And this delu≈øion deceives thou≈øands of people, e≈øpecially morallized, and civillized men; they runne hoodwinkt to hell, nouri≈øhing hopes of life and ≈øalvation, and never feele the contrary, till they come
to death and hell. I ≈øhall declare this to be a delu≈øion, in laying down four or five particulars. As,

Fir≈øt, That there are many men, that are mentioned in Scripture, not to have been within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, who yet were men of very blamele≈ø≈øe and hone≈øt lives, not blemi≈øhed with any gro≈ø≈øe and ≈øcandalous evils.
