Read Luke 18.11, 14. of the Phari≈øee. He tels you, he thanks God he was no extortioner, no adulterer, no covetous per≈øon, no drunkard, nor was he as wicked as the Publican was. Here you ≈øee a man that ≈øpake vauntingly and truely, that he was not a man that broke out into tho≈øe mi≈øcarriages other men did; yet what was this man? An elect ve≈ø≈øell? No. Read ver≈ø. 14. and the Text tels you, the Publican went away ju≈øtified, rather then the other; the Phari≈øee, though he was free from ≈øcandalous and gro≈ø≈øe enormities in his life, yet he was not a ju≈øtified man, and ≈øo by con≈øequence not an elect man. You read of Hypocrites, Matth. 23. that clean≈øed the out≈øide of the cup and of the platter, that is, clean≈øed their conver≈øations, and clean≈øed the outward man of gro≈ø≈øe ≈øcandals, and yet within were full of filth; and Chri≈øt tels us, they were hypocrites, that ≈øhould have their portion in hell. And ≈øhould you view over Hi≈øtorians that write of the Scribes and Phari≈øees, and ≈øtrict men among the Jewes, they will tell you what wonderfull holy-lived men they were; they were often in duties, fa≈øted twice a week, prayed every day in the corners of the ≈øtreets; none ≈øo ≈øtrict as they in ob≈øerving the Sabbath; would goe vailed, le≈øt they ≈øhould be en≈ønared by la≈øcivious objects; and yet the≈øe very men ≈øo wonderfull ≈øtrict, and cautious, were men that had no dram of grace in them at all. Though they were a people thus well dre≈ø≈øed in their lives, yet the Scripture tels us of them, that Whores and Harlots ≈øhould goe to Heaven before them. This therefore is the fir≈øt, that many men have had their lives free from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øcandals, and yet were men that were not elected by God to life and ≈øalvation.

Secondly, that a mans conver≈øation may be free from ≈øcandalous ≈øinnes, yet if this freedome from ≈øcandals proceed from a wrong principle, it may be in a per≈øon not elected. As I will
make it appeare. There may be a freedome from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes proceeding from a threefold principle, and yet a man be in a ≈øtate of damnation and of reprobation. As fir≈øt, There may be a freedome from ≈øcandals, proceeding from religious education; ≈øecondly, from a naturall di≈øpo≈øition; and thirdly, from the power of re≈øtraining grace. Fir≈øt, there may be a freedome from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes, proceeding from the power of education. So the young man in the Go≈øpell, Matth. 19.18, 19, 20. when Chri≈øt told him what the Law was. Thou ≈øhalt not commit adultery, thou ≈øhalt not ≈øteale, thou ≈øhalt love thy neighbour as thy ≈øelfe, thou ≈øhalt doe no murder, thou ≈øhalt not beare fal≈øe witne≈ø≈øe, &c. Saith the young man, All the≈øe have I kept from my youth. He was a Phari≈øee, and his parents ≈øtrict in their cour≈øe of living, and brought him up ≈øo from his youth; and yet this man no elect man, ver≈ø. 22. Secondly, a man may be free from ≈øcandalous ≈øins, ari≈øing from an ingenious naturall di≈øpo≈øition. A mans di≈øpo≈øition may ≈øometimes be utterly aver≈øe to ≈øome ≈øinnes. Plutarch a heathen could ≈øay this, I had rather it were ≈øaid, there were no ≈øuch man as Plutarch in the world, then to ≈øay, that Plutarch was uncha≈øte, Plutarch was a drunkard, or Plutarch was a ≈øwearer. Mans naturall temper may ≈øometimes be free from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes, and yet he not an elect per≈øon for all this. And then thirdly, a man may be free from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes, as proceeding from the power of re≈øtraining grace, Gen. 20.6. I al≈øo withheld Abimelech from ≈øinning again≈øt me. He was a heathen, and a wicked man, and yet God, by the power of re≈øtraining grace, did keepe Abimelech from running into that exorbitant cour≈øe of ≈øinning again≈øt him. So that if a man be free from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes, and yet proceeding from fal≈øe principles, a man may not be an elect man for all this. Unle≈ø≈øe your freedome from ≈øinne proceed from a renewed nature, from a ≈øanctified heart, and from the ≈øaving operation of the holy gho≈øt; unle≈ø≈øe it comes from the≈øe principles, your freedome from gro≈ø≈øe ≈øinnes can be no pledge to your ≈øoules, that you are elected by God to life.

Thirdly, that a man having a good life, free from ≈øcandalous
≈øinnes, if he have not a good heart, that is no argument of a man that is within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, Rom. 2.28, 29. He is not a Jew, which is one outwardly; nor is that circumci≈øion, which is outward in the fle≈øh, but he is a Jew, which is one inwardly, and circumci≈øion is of the heart, who≈øe prai≈øe is not of men, but of God. Intimating, that he is not a Chri≈øtian; he is not an elect Jew, that was one outwardly; that is, that was conformable to the rites and cu≈øtomes of the Jewes; but he was one that was one inwardly, that had his ≈øinnes mortified, his nature changed, and his heart clean≈øed, he was an elect Jew. So that to have a holy life, if a man have not an holy heart, is no ≈øign that a man is within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election.

Fourthly, God in electing men to life, doth pa≈ø≈øe by morall and civill hone≈øt men, that tru≈øt and depend upon their own righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe and ≈øtrict living, rather then any ≈øort of men in the World. Matth. 21.31, 33. ≈øaith Chri≈øt, John Bapti≈øt preached the Go≈øpel of repentance, but you believed not, but publicans and harlots believed. Tho≈øe Phari≈øees that did depend upon their own righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, & their own goodne≈ø≈øe, Chri≈øt did not call them, Chri≈øt did not own them, God made them not the objects of his election. Hence it is ≈øaid, Matth. 9.13. Chri≈øt came not to call the righteous, but ≈øinners to repentance: that is, men depending upon their own righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, and their own parts, they are left out by Chri≈øt, as if he came not for them; but Chri≈øt came to call ≈øinners, that ≈øee their ≈øinne, and were vile in their own eyes, Chri≈øt came to call ≈øuch. Againe,

2. The ≈øecond delu≈øion, whereby the divel makes men think they are elected by God, is drawn from their externall vocation; that they are not onely civilized, and moralized ones, but they finde the power of the word to call them; and upon this vocation they bottom the hopes of their election. And they have Scripture for it, Rom. 8.30. Whom God prede≈øtinates he calls. Now God hath called them by the word, and they have found the word come with power upon their con≈øcience, to reforme the evils of their life. (And the power of
vocation they deem higher (as indeed it is) then the power of education, or naturall temper;) and therefore, think they, I having vocation, this is an evidence to me of my election. To this delu≈øion I ≈øhall only ≈øay two things, by way of an≈øwer.

Fir≈øt, it is true indeed, the Scripture ≈øaith, all whom God prede≈øtinates, he calls; but the Scripture doth not ≈øay, that all whom he calls, he prede≈øtinates. No man that God appoints to life, but before he dies, God will call him by the word; but God doth not ≈øay any where, that tho≈øe whom he cals, them he did prede≈øtinate to life.

Secondly, many men are outwardly called by the word into a profe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, when they are not eternally elected by God to ≈øalvation. Matth. 22.14. Many are called, but few are cho≈øen. Many are called, but all tho≈øe that are externally called by the word, are not cho≈øen, nor all ordained to life. A man may be called from ignorance to knowledge, yet not elected. Heb. 6.4. After they were enlightned, and had ta≈øted the word of God, and the power of the world to come, yet they fell away. A man may be called from profanene≈ø≈øe to profe≈ø≈øion, from the world into the Church, as Simon Magus was, yet not elected, but remaine in the gall of bitterne≈ø≈øe, and bond of iniquity.

Thirdly, A third delu≈øion, whereby men are deceived by the divell, to think they are elected, when they are not is this, If they cannot plead their education, and morall manner of living, or if they cannot plead their vocation, their la≈øt plea is, the mercy of God; they hope God is a mercifull God, and God made them not all to damne them; they are Gods creatures, made by him, and God that made them, will ≈øave them; and hereupon they fa≈øten their hopes, that they are in the number of Gods elect ones. This is a ≈øtrong delu≈øion, e≈øpecially among≈øt ignorant people. And to this I ≈øhall an≈øwer in two particulars.

Fir≈øt, when as men ≈øay, God is a mercifull God, therefore they hope they are elected, I an≈øwer: It is true, God is a mercifull God, yet God is as ju≈øt as mercifull; he is mercifully ju≈øt, and ju≈øtly mercifull; his mercy cannot intrench
upon his ju≈øtice, nor ≈øhall his ju≈øtice intrench upon his mercy; one Attribute ≈øhall not cla≈øh with another; he is no more mercifull, then he is ju≈øt, nor is he more ju≈øt then he is mercifull.

Secondly, though God be a mercifull God, yet Gods ≈øaving mercy is not ≈øo large as to extend to all creatures that live, that he hath made. You read E≈øay 27.11. This is a people of no under≈øtanding, therefore hee that made them will not have mercy upon them, and he that formed them will ≈øhew them no favour. Here you ≈øee, the Prophet tels them, that that God that made them will damne them, and that God that formed them, that God will ≈øhew them no favour. So that Gods mercy extends not ≈øo farre, as to reach to all the works of his hands; for if ≈øo, the divels might claime ≈øalvation as well as man; for God made them when they were glorious Angels, as well as man: and therefore, if all the works of Gods hands ≈øhould plead for ≈øalvation, they might as well come within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, as wicked men doe.

And thus you ≈øee in the≈øe ≈øeverall Sermons, I have fini≈øhed the Doctrines of Effectuall Vocation, and Eternall election. I will now a little illu≈øtrate the point, by laying down ten Propo≈øitions, which will ≈øerve to cleare the Doctrine of Election in many points about it, and ≈øo conclude.

Fir≈øt, That all men are not the objects of Gods election, or of Gods choice. And this propo≈øition doth confute the opinion of Origen. Origen was of this mind, that all mankind ≈øhould be ≈øaved, nay, the very divels them≈øelves, they ≈øhould all be ≈øaved by Chri≈øt. A mo≈øt groundle≈ø≈øe, and unheard of opinion; for all men are not elected to ≈øalvation. Jude tels us, in his Epi≈øtle, there were ≈øome of old ordained to condemnation; and if ≈øo, ≈øurely they could not fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, 1 The≈ø. 5.9. There are ≈øome ordained to wrath; but we are not among≈øt them ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle, but we are ordained to obtaine ≈øalvation by Je≈øus Chri≈øt. All are not objects of Gods election to life.

Secondly, that the fewe≈øt ≈øort of men and women that God
hath made are the the objects of his election. God in his own coun≈øell hath elected to life and ≈øalvation the fewe≈øt ≈øort of men and women in the world. And this is a very dreadfull point, Many are called, but few are cho≈øen. Matth. 22.14. Rom. 11.5. A remnant, according to the election of grace. And here in pur≈øuing this head, I ≈øhall lay down two things under this propo≈øition: Fir≈øt, that there are but few rich men cho≈øen by God to life and ≈øalvation. Secondly, there are but few civill hone≈øt men cho≈øen by God to life and ≈øalvation. There are but few rich men that fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods purpo≈øe to ≈øave, 1 Cor. 1.26. Not many mighty, (he doth not ≈øay, not any; but not many mighty) not many Noble, not many great ones of the world are cho≈øen. You read Matth. 19.24. That it is as ea≈øie for a Camell to goe thorough a Needles eye, as for a rich man to enter into the Kingdome of God. As ea≈øie for a Camell. It is not meant in this ≈øence, as ≈øome expound it. That there was a gate in Hieru≈øalem, called the Needles eye; a little and low gate, which their Camels being laden could not goe through, and therefore they mu≈øt unload the burden, and the Camell ≈øtoop before they could enter. Some think Chri≈øts ≈øpeech had relation to that Beza ≈øaith, that in≈øtead of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a Camel, they read „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a Cable; which, if untwi≈øted may be put through the eye of a Needle, but the knot is not untied, but cut by this expo≈øition. But the words were a proverbiall ≈øpeech among the Jewes, who had this proverb among≈øt them, that when any one ≈øpake things either unlikely or unprobable, they would ≈øay, This can be as ea≈øily done, as a Camel can goe through a Needles eye. And Chri≈øt, alluding to this Proverb, ≈øaith, that rich men, that dote upon their riches, and cleave to their wealth, and rather part with heaven, and Chri≈øt, and ≈øoule and all, then part with their riches, Chri≈øt makes it an unpo≈ø≈øible thing for ≈øuch rich men to come into heaven. As I once told what Buchanan ≈øaid, lying upon his death-bed in a me≈ø≈øage to King James, I am going to that place, where few Kings come. And, beloved, the ≈øpeech is true, for not many wi≈øe, not many mighty, not many Noble hath the Lord cho≈øen. Secondly, few civill hone≈øt men doe fall
within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods choyce to ≈øave. Morall men, that tru≈øt upon their civility and morall hone≈øty, and plain dealing; few or none of the≈øe come to Heaven. Publicans and Harlots ≈øhall come to Heaven before you. Matth. 21.32. Whores and harlots believe in me, when you doe not, ≈øaith Chri≈øt.

Thirdly, that though God in his own coun≈øell, hath determined, or made choice but of the fewe≈øt number of men and women to life and ≈øalvation, yet this doth no way intrench upon the mercy of God, this doth no way le≈ø≈øen or impeach the mercy of God. Men may think, as if ≈øurely God had ca≈øt off all bowels, and ca≈øt off all mercy. What? God make ≈øuch a world of men as he hath done, and ≈øave but a few of the≈øe? Man might think, as if God were a hard ma≈øter, that delighted in the de≈øtruction of man, that had forgotten to be gracious; ≈øuch a hard charge will they be apt to lay upon God. But now, beloved, that God hath elected ≈øo few a number to life, this doth no way impeach the mercy of God. And this I make appeare thus: becau≈øe God was bound to ≈øave none at all; therefore you cannot challenge God either with unmercifulne≈ø≈øe, or unfaithfulne≈ø≈øe, if he ≈øhould ≈øave none. It was a meer act of his bounty and good will, that he would ≈øave any. Nay, ≈øecondly, there is that in man, in the be≈øt of men, that might ju≈øtly provoke God not to ≈øave any: And therefore if God ≈øave any, it is of grace. And this is a certain rule, that God doth ≈øhew more mercy in ≈øaving of one, then he would have done rigour of ju≈øtice, had he damned all. As may be made plain by this compari≈øon. Suppo≈øe fourty men guilty of Rebellion were arraigned for their lives, and were condemned to die by the Law; if the Prince pardon foure of the≈øe forty, he ≈øhewes more mercy in pardoning the foure, then he doth rigour of ju≈øtice in condemning the forty. Why? becau≈øe the fact de≈øerved death, in all alike. So it is with God: every man upon earth de≈øerves death and damnation; & if God cull out any of the ma≈ø≈øe of mankind, to ≈øave them, he ≈øhewes more mercy, then he had done rigorous ju≈øtice, ≈øhould he have de≈øtroyed all, becau≈øe he is bound to ≈øave none at all.

Fourthly, God in electing a certain number to life, doth it without fore≈øight of any good works which he ≈øaw would be in them. Indeed the Papi≈øts and Arminians joyn their ≈øtrength, to maintaine this; God, ≈øay they, fore≈øaw men would believe in Chri≈øt, and would be holy in their lives, and therefore God did chu≈øe them to life. This you may remember I ≈øpent ≈øome time in overthrowing formerly, and therefore pa≈øs it over now. viz. That God did not chu≈øe men to life, with reference to any good works he fore≈øaw in them. This indeed is an undoubted truth; All men whom God did elect to life, he fore≈øaw they would have good works in them; but Gods fore≈øeeing of this, was not the cau≈øe for which God did elect them. No, the motive was his own will, according to the plea≈øure of his own grace, Rom. 9.11. and Rom. 11.5. A remnant are ≈øaved according to the election of grace, for if it were of works, grace is no more grace. Were election upon fore≈øight of good workes, then it would follow, that infants dying in infancy were not within the compa≈ø≈øe of Gods election, becau≈øe an infant ≈øo dying, could not performe any good works; and ≈øo their ca≈øe would be mo≈øt mi≈øerable. Be≈øides, we are not ju≈øtified by actuall workes, therefore not elected upon works fore≈øeen. Rom. 3.24. for there is the like rea≈øon of the≈øe two.

Fifthly, That Gods election is ≈øo free, that in chu≈øing and electing men to life and ≈øalvation, he doth not doe it for the ≈øake of Je≈øus Chri≈øt him≈øelfe. Under≈øtand this well, that therein you might both give Chri≈øt his due, and God the father his due: for mi≈øtake me not. God doth ≈øave none but by Chri≈øt, but God did elect men without reference to Je≈øus Chri≈øt as the motive of election, meerly according to the purpo≈øe of his own will. All modern and latter Divines lay down this for a truth, that it was the meere plea≈øure, and good will of God to man, that was the motive of Gods electing us, and not Chri≈øt. Chri≈øt could not be the cau≈øe, becau≈øe he was the effect. Now what is the effect, cannot be the cau≈øe. Gods love in electing mankind, did produce Je≈øus Chri≈øt to be the meanes of our ≈øalvation, and of bringing about Gods
election, therefore he being the effect of election cannot be the cau≈øe. The cau≈øe of election was eternall, but the merits of Chri≈øt were not ≈øo. Again, Chri≈øt was elected him≈øelfe. 1 Pet. 1.20. He was preordained of God before the World was. Now he that was elected him≈øelf, could not be the cau≈øe of our election. Be≈øides the elect are ≈øaid to be given to Chri≈øt to be ≈øaved, John 17.2. therefore he was not the cau≈øe of our election. It is true, the Scripture tels us, Eph. 1.4. We are elected in Chri≈øt, i. we are elected in Chri≈øt as a common per≈øon. God fir≈øt cho≈øe Chri≈øt, and then believers in Chri≈øt, as menbers of his body. But God elects no man for Chri≈øts ≈øake, but man is cho≈øen meerly of Gods bounty, without reference to Je≈øus Chri≈øt. And here Divines ≈øay, Gods love in electing man to life was as free, as if Chri≈øt had never died; and it was ≈øo free, that man was not beholding to Chri≈øt for his election; and yet Chri≈øts ≈øufferings were ≈øo full, as if men were not bound to God for their election. Thus they are plea≈øed to expre≈ø≈øe it. And the rea≈øon why the Scripture ≈øpeakes th ‚Ä¢ s, that we are onely cho≈øen in Chri≈øt, not for Chri≈øt, is to give God the Father his due in electing men to life: that God did it meerly of his own grace, and therein Gods love and favour is apparent to all the world, that he did elect man without Chri≈øt, as the motive of his election: and yet Je≈øus Chri≈øt being come into the world, he carries on our ≈øalvation, and he is the cau≈øe of it; though he was not the cau≈øe of Gods fir≈øt thoughts, in electing man to life.

6. All men that are elected by God to life and ≈øalvation ≈øhall ≈øooner or later before they die be called into a ≈øtate of conver≈øion, and believing, Rom. 8.30. Whom he did prede≈øtinate, them he al≈øo called: and Acts 13.48. As many as were ordained to eternall life believed. So that God the father, in ordaining man to life, hath ordained this al≈øo, that before they die, they ≈øhall be a converted and believing people, and therfore men remaining unconverted, uncalled, unbelieving, they are not the objects of Gods election.

Seventhly, that God in chu≈øing or electing men to life, doth let his election runne ordinarily unto the meane≈øt, and unto
the wor≈øt ≈øort of men in the world, men that have lea≈øt naturall endowments, le≈øt morall excellencies, lea≈øt worldly gallantry; ordinarily election runs that way. God hath cho≈øen the poore things of this world, and things de≈øpi≈øed, and things that are not hath he cho≈øen. 1 Cor. 1.27. Jam. 2.5. Hath not God cho≈øen the poore of this world to be rich in faith. Ordinarily the Lord chu≈øeth poor and meane men, that have no naturall or morall excellencies. Hence it was that when Chri≈øt left the learned Phari≈øees, and Doctors among the Jewes, the ignorant and poore people, they flocked after Je≈øus Chri≈øt; they looked after Je≈øus Chri≈øt, when the rich and great men of the world had no ≈øhare in him.

Eighthly, that a man may be an elect child of God, and yet not expre≈ø≈øe the fruit of his election in many yeeres here in the world, and this is a very comfortable point. An in≈øtance you have of this in Paul. It is ob≈øervable of Paul, the Scripture tels us he was a cho≈øen ve≈ø≈øell, Acts 9.15. and yet Paul lived many yeeres, before the fruit of his election appeared in him. Some Hi≈øtorians ≈øay, Paul lived 37. the lea≈øt ≈øay 30 yeers, before the fruit of election appeared in him, for he was converted the very yeere after Chri≈øts death; and all the while before, he did expre≈ø≈øe fruit that was ≈øeemingly repugnant to an elect e≈øtate, as if a man could not be an elect ve≈ø≈øell, that was ≈øo vile as he: he was a bla≈øpheme, a per≈øecuter, injurious to the Church, haled men to pri≈øon, mad with rage again≈øt the profe≈ø≈øors of Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Nay, he was a man that had a hand in putting Steven the fir≈øt Martyr to death. So long he lived in a cour≈øe of iniquity, for 30. yeeres together, and yet this man was an elect ve≈ø≈øell then. So the Thiefe upon the Cro≈ø≈øe, an elect child of God, yet did not expre≈ø≈øe the fruit of his election in repentance and conver≈øion, untill the la≈øt houre of his life. So that I ≈øay a man may be an elect childe of God, and yet not expre≈ø≈øe the fruit of his election in his life for many yeeres.

Ninthly, that God for the great love he beares to his elect that are in the world, lets Reprobates and wicked men enjoy many mercies and outward deliverances, for their ≈øakes. Mark 13.19, 20. There ≈øhall be tribulation, ≈øaith Chri≈øt, ≈øuch as was
not from the beginning of the world, nor ≈øhall be to the end thereof: but for the elect ≈øake tho≈øe daies ≈øhall be ≈øhortned. For his elect ≈øake, God did mitigate, did ≈øhorten, God did take away that trouble from them. So E≈øa. 1.9. Had not God le≈øt us a ≈ømall remnant, we had been like Sodome, yea like unto Gomorrha. Had not God left a handfull of his elect and godly men among≈øt them, all the re≈øt had been de≈øtroyed. So E≈øa. 65.8. And the Lord ≈øaid, de≈øtroy not the people, for a ble≈ø≈øing is among them. That is, my people is among them, and my elect is among them, therefore de≈øtroy them not. God did not de≈øtroy the Nation of the Jewes, becau≈øe God had his own people mixed among them. So Job 22.30. And this conclu≈øion admini≈øters matter of thankfulne≈ø≈øe, to all men upon earth, to make you ble≈ø≈øe God, that he keepes his people alive among you, for it is for the elects ≈øake you have all the outward ble≈ø≈øings and mercies you doe enjoy.

Tenthly and la≈øtly, take in this conclu≈øion: That this world ≈øhall continue no longer, then till the number of Gods elect be accompli≈øhed; when God hath accompli≈øhed, and brought in to Chri≈øt the number of his elect; the world ≈øhall not ≈øtand one minute longer after this worke is done. God doth but uphold the world, till the full number of Jewes and Gentiles be come in. If the number were filled, Je≈øus Chri≈øt would ≈øurrender up the Kingdome to his Father. The Heavens ≈øhould gather together like a ≈øcrowle, and the Elements ≈øhould melt with fervent heat, and this world ≈øhould come to a di≈ø≈øolution. It is the elect in the world, that keep up the world, that it doth not fall about our eares. And thus having ≈øpent the≈øe 16 Sermons touching mans Effectuall calling, and eternall Election, I have now brought all unto a conclu≈øion. And I earne≈øtly intreat you, let it be your work, to put forth your diligence to make this ≈øure to your own ≈øoules, that you are effectually called, and that you are eternally elected to obtaine life and ≈øalvation by Je≈øus Chri≈øt.
